A mobile home is distinguished from the manufactured home as defined herein. (Ord. of 9-1-05) Sec. 50-2. - Penalty for violation of chapter. Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction in the municipal court, be punished as provided in section 1-13 of this Code. (Ord. of 9-1-05) Secs. 50-3—50-9. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - MANUFACTURED HOME PARKS DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 50-10. - Scope. The provisions of this article apply to manufactured home parks. (Ord. of 9-1-05) Sec. 50-11. - Exception to construction provisions of this chapter. Provisions of this article relating to construction shall not apply to manufactured home parks in existence on ____________ , 2005, except that any alteration of any portion of these parks shall be made in accordance with the applicable provision of this article. (Ord. of 9-1-05) Sec. 50-12. - Inspection. Manufactured home park buildings and premises shall be subject to inspection by the mayor and council. (Ord. of 9-1-05) Sec. 50-13. - Registry of occupants. Persons operating manufactured home parks shall maintain a registry of all occupants in manufactured home parks. (Ord. of 9-1-05) Sec. 50-14. - Numbering of manufactured or industrial homes. All manufactured and industrial homes shall be required to have building numbers as required by section 18-9 of this Code. (Ord. of 9-1-05) Secs. 50-15—50-35. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - PERMITS
Sec. 50-36. - Construction of alteration permit required. Manufactured home parks shall not be constructed or altered by any person until the mayor and council has given formal approval therefor for issuance of a permit. (Ord. of 9-1-05) Sec. 50-37. - Requisites for issuance. Permits to construct shall not be issued until the mayor and council has inspected and approved the proposed manufactured home park site and has received and approved final plans, specifications and reports prepared by a licensed surveyor/and professional engineer or registered architect fully describing and setting forth all data as hereinafter required or as may otherwise be required by the mayor and council. (Ord. of 9-1-05) Sec. 50-38. - Final plans; preparation; data required. An applicant shall submit to the city planning commission for approval the final plans, specifications, and reports prepared by a licensed professional engineer or registered architect which shall include the following data: (1) Plot plan showing: a. Area and dimensions of tract; b. Streams, watercourses and any proposed diversions; c. Contours or original grades and proposed grade changes; d. Service buildings or other proposed structures; e. Roads and walkways; f. Water and sewer lines; g. Fire hydrants and drinking fountains; h. Size and arrangement of trailer coach spaces; i. Playground and open space areas; and j. Refuse storage stations; (2) Detail plans and specifications of service buildings, roads, walks and other proposed construction; and (3) Detail plans and specifications of water supply, sewerage and electrical facilities. (4) Test results on soil, ground water level, drainage, rock formations, and topography; (5) Such other plan elements, design standards, and controls as may be deemed reasonably necessary by the planning commission to accomplish the purposes of this chapter. The planning commission may disapprove, approve or modify the plans in order to assure the development of a manufactured home park in accordance with the purposes of this chapter. When such development plans have been approved, they shall be certified to the city administrator by the chairman of the planning commission and then submitted to mayor and council for final approval. (Ord. of 9-1-05) Sec. 50-39. - Alterations. (a) A permit to alter a manufactured home park shall not be issued until the mayor and council have received a letter of application therefor, together with such plans, specifications, or reports as may be requested by the mayor and council to fully describe the proposed alteration. (b) Upon compliance with all applicable provisions of this article and approval of the requested alternation or proposal, a permit shall be issued for the alteration. (Ord. of 9-1-05) Secs. 50-40—50-55. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - GENERAL DEVELOPMENT STANDARDS
Sec. 50-56. - General development requirements. The standards in this section shall apply to all manufactured home parks. (1) Site conditions. Planned manufactured home parks shall be sited on land that is not subject to hazards such as flooding, erosion, land subsidence, and areas with possible insect or rodent infestation. The condition of the soil, ground water level, drainage, rock formations, and topography must be appropriate for the use, to ensure that no hazards to the property or to the health and safety of the occupants occur. (2) Site planning. Planning for manufactured home parks should be adapted to individual site conditions and the type of use or uses served, reflect advances in site planning techniques, and be adapted to the trends in the design of the manufactured home itself. Site planning and improvements shall provide for facilities and amenities appropriate to the needs of the occupants, safe, comfortable and sanitary use by the occupants under all weather conditions, and practical and efficient operation and maintenance of all facilities at reasonable costs. The street and block pattern for the park shall be designed to attain proper sizes and shapes of manufactured homes spaces so as to provide desirable areas and to reduce excessive length of street construction without impairing convenient circulation and access. (3) Minimum site area, site frontage, access, and minimum width. Manufactured home parks shall contain a minimum area of five acres. Properties containing manufactured home parks shall have a minimum of 200 feet of property frontage on a public street, and directly access the public street with a minimum of 200 feet of property frontage. Manufactured home parks shall have a minimum lot width of 200 feet throughout the entire depth of the developed portion of the property. (4) Perimeter buffer or landscape screen. A minimum 20-foot wide buffer, where natural vegetation exists and provides a more or less opaque screen, or where no natural vegetation forming an opaque screen exists, a minimum 20-foot wide landscape strip with evergreen trees that will grow to a height of at least six feet within three years, shall be installed and maintained around the entire perimeter of the manufactured home park, except for approval access and utility crossings. (5) Open space and recreational areas. A manufactured home park serving 20 or more dwellings, shall have a minimum of 20 percent of the site area dedicated to open space and passive or active recreation, including the required perimeter buffer or landscape screen. (6) Community services. As part of the development plan review process, the developer may propose and the city may approve one or more other structures for manufactured home park occupants, such as laundries, storage, garages, and a park leasing or management office. Any structure that draws its trade from outside the park boundaries is prohibited. (7) Interior access roads, addresses, and signs. The road system within the manufactured home park shall be designed to meet the requirements of the city fire chief and the traveling public to include the following: all interior roads shall be private but constructed to provide fire apparatus access. Roads within manufactured home parks shall be paved. Signs shall be installed as required by the city and approved in the development plan review process. (8) Road specifications. One-way interior roads shall be constructed with a minimum surface width of 12 feet, with three feet of shoulder on each side, and shall be designated "no parking." The right-of-way for said one-way interior roads shall be 24 feet. Two-way interior roads shall be constructed with a minimum surface width of 20 feet, with three feet of shoulder on each side, and shall be designated "no parking." The right-of-way for said two-way interior roads shall be 40 feet. Interior roads shall be clearly marked at each intersection with signs to identify traffic directions and space numbers served by the road. Driveways shall be provided on the site where necessary for convenient access to service entrances of buildings, to delivery and collection points for refuse disposal, and elsewhere as needed. Street lighting may be required. (9) Guest parking. In addition to on-site parking, guest parking spaces shall be provided as part of the development, at a ratio of one parking space per each two manufactured homes in a manufactured home park. Guest parking spaces shall be grouped and distributed evenly throughout the park. (10) Utilities. All manufactured home parks, and each manufactured home space within the park, shall be served by approved water system, sanitary sewer system, and electricity. Fire hydrants shall be installed at 500-foot intervals so that no manufactured home space is more than 250 feet from a hydrant. All utilities shall be installed underground with above-ground connections. (11) Street lighting. Street lights shall be provided in accordance with city specifications by the developer of a manufactured home park prior to occupancy. (12) Drainage. Drainage facilities shall be designed by an engineer and are subject to the approval of the city as part of the development plan review process. (13) Refuse collection. Each manufactured home park shall provide refuse collection pads at locations convenient to each manufactured home space. (14) Occupancy restriction. Recreational vehicles shall not be permanently occupied as a residence within manufactured home parks. (15) Solid waste disposal. One or more solid waste collection areas shall be required. The number of spaces shall be used to determine the number of disposal sites required. The locations shall be proposed by the applicant and as approved in the development review process. Collection areas having more than one container require screening with a sight-obscuring fence. (Ord. of 9-1-05) Sec. 50-57. - Manufactured home space requirements. The development standards of this section shall apply to all manufactured home parks. (1) Design. Each manufactured home shall be designed and constructed at such elevation, distance, and angle with respect to its access to provide for safe and efficient placement and removal of manufactured homes. Spaces for manufactured homes shall be designed with no more than a five percent gradient and compacted with appropriate material to support maximum anticipated loads during all seasons. (2) Width, depth, and size of spaces and markings. Lot sizing requirements for mobile home parks will comply with those set forth in Code Section 70-63(2)(b). The corners of each manufactured home space shall be clearly marked on the ground by permanent flush stakes, markers, or by other similar means. Spaces served by community or public water and individual septic tanks shall maintain a minimum space area as established and approved by the health officer. (3) Use of spaces. No more than one manufactured or industrial home shall occupy any individual space. Accessory uses and structures on individual spaces may be permitted, subject to compliance with the development standards provided in this article. (4) Space identification numbers. Manufactured home space numbers at least four inches in height; shall be stenciled on the curbs using fluorescent paint; and, shall identify each space and shall remain readily identifiable while in use. (5) Parking. Two on-site parking spaces shall be provided on each manufactured home space or immediately off-site. (6) Setbacks. No manufactured or industrial home shall be located closer than five feet to home or vehicle space boundary, and spaces shall be designed to provide for a minimum of 20 feet of separation between manufactured or industrial homes on abutting spaces. (7) Additions and accessory structures. Decks, porches, outdoor storage, or other exterior additions may be constructed or erected on a manufactured home space, subject to the approval of the community or park management. No such accessory structure shall be located closer than five feet to a manufactured home space boundary. (Ord. of 9-1-05; Ord. No. 2010-11, § 2, 8-16-10)) Secs. 50-58—50-79. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - LOCATION OF MANUFACTURED HOMES
Sec. 50-80. - Manufactured homes possessing certain characteristics of site-built dwellings. (a) Permitted locations. Subject to requirements and limitations set forth in this chapter including, but not limited to, the standards set forth in subsections 50-80(b) and 50-82(b), manufactured homes possessing the following characteristics of site-built dwellings shall be allowed in R-A and R-2 residential zoning districts and shall be regulated uniformly with other housing constructed on site: (1) Minimum width in excess of 16 feet: (2) Minimum square footage required by the zone in which located. (3) The roof shall have a minimum 4:12 roof pitch and shall have a surface of wood shakes, asphalt composition, wood shingles, concrete, fiberglass files, slate, built up gravel materials, or other materials approved by the building official. (4) The exterior siding materials shall consist of wood, masonry, concrete, stucco, masonite, metal or vinyl lap or other materials of like appearance, and shall extend to a solid concrete or masonry perimeter skirting. Such skirting shall be constructed in accordance with the current edition of the International Residential Code for One and Two Family Dwellings (ICC) as amended and adopted by the State of Georgia. (5) Be attached to a permanent foundation constructed in accordance with either the current edition of the International Residential Code for One and Two Family Dwellings (ICC) as amended and adopted by the State of Georgia, or the National Manufactured Housing Construction and Safety Standards Act for Manufactured Homes (HUD). (6) Be constructed according to standards established by the National Manufactured Housing Construction and Safety Standards Act for Manufactured Homes. (7) Exterior steps, landings and porches provided at all entrances constructed in accordance with the current edition of the International Residential Code for One and Two Family Dwellings (ICC) as amended and adopted by the State of Georgia. (8) The unit shall be oriented on the lot so that its long axis is parallel with the street. A perpendicular or diagonal placement may be permitted if there is a section addition so that the narrow dimension of the unit, as so modified and facing the street, is no less than 50 percent of the unit's long dimension. The narrowest dimension of any unit, including additions, placed in a perpendicular or diagonal position to the street shall be at least 16 feet with a maximum depth of 16 feet. Approval shall be in accordance with section 50-84. (b) Compatibility standards for manufactured homes possessing characteristics of site-built dwellings are as follows: Manufactured homes possessing the characteristics of site-built dwellings as set forth in subsection 50-80(a) shall be compared to site-built and other housing in the immediate general area within the same zoning or residential district or area. Approval for their location in R-A and R-2 residential zoning districts shall be granted upon the finding that the manufactured home is subsequently similar or superior in size, siding material, roof material, foundation and general aesthetic appearance to: (i) site-built or other forms of housing which may be permitted in the same general area under this chapter or (ii) existing development, or (iii) proposed development in the same zoning district or area. (Ord. of 9-1-05; Ord. No. 2017-9, § 1, 10-16-17) Sec. 50-81. - Industrial homes possessing characteristics of site-built dwellings. (a) Permitted locations. Industrial homes possessing characteristics of site-built dwellings as set forth in section 50-80 shall be allowed in R-A or R-2 residential districts and shall be regulated uniformly with other housing constructed on site, subject to requirements and limitations set forth in this chapter. Approval shall be in accordance with section 50-84. (Ord. of 9-1-05) Sec. 50-82. - Other manufactured homes used for residential purposes. (a) Permitted locations. Manufactured and industrial homes which do not possess characteristics of site-built dwellings set forth in subsection 50-80(a) or meet the compatibility standards set forth in subsection 50-80(b) shall only be permitted within areas designated as manufactured home parks provided that each structure complies with the following standards: (1) Structure must be connected to the water and sewerage system including well and septic tank approved by the city/county health department. (2) In the event minimum installation standards have not been adopted by the State of Georgia, the structure must be installed according to the manufacturer's installation instructions when available or Appendix "H" of the Georgia State Building Code. (3) The area beneath each such structure must be enclosed with materials manufactured for such purposes, including but not limited to brick, concrete, rock or other materials which have been approved by the city building inspector. (4) All structures must have footings and piers in accordance with the following: a. All footings for piers will consist of two four-inch by eight-inch by 16-inch cap blocks set side by side as a pad on pre-leveled firm dirt. All grass, leaves, trash, and loose dirt will be removed before pad is set. b. Eight-inch by eight-inch by 16-inch cement blocks are to be used for piers. All blocks will be stacked, level, holes down on footings. All piers will be no more than eight feet apart. c. All piers for structures set on property other than an established manufactured home park will be double blocked. d. All piers that exceed four blocks high, excluding footings and top cap blocks, will be double blocked. e. All piers that are double blocked will be double blocked from footings to frame, including top cap blocks. f. No more than three inches of wood shall be used as shimes, excluding wedges. g. No structure shall be blocked in a manner where front or rear piers exceed seven blocks high, excluding footings and top cap blocks. h. Requirement g. above, in certain cases, may be waived by the city building official. (5) All structures must be anchored in accordance with the following: a. Manufactured or industrial homes 40 feet or less will have at least eight tie downs, one for every five feet. b. Manufactured or industrial homes over 40 feet will have at least ten tie downs, one for every four feet. c. All structures to be placed within zone A on a community's FHBM or FIRM shall be installed using methods and practices which minimize flood damage. For the purposes of this requirement, structures must be elevated and anchored to resist flotation, collapse, or lateral movement. Methods of anchoring may include, but are not limited to, use of over-the-top or frame ties to ground anchors. This requirement is in addition to applicable state and local anchoring requirements for resisting wind forces. All structures shall be elevated above the base level and anchored to the elevated foundation. (Ord. of 9-1-05) Sec. 50-83. - Special exceptions. Manufactured and industrial homes which do not possess characteristics of site-built dwelling set forth in subsection 50-80(a), or meet the compatibility standards set forth in subsection 50-80(b), may be permitted as a hardship dwelling use on lots outside of manufactured home parks as follows: (1) Any permit issued under these conditions shall be issued only after a finding by the zoning board of appeals that a hardship situation exists because of a medical disability and that the unit would not adversely affect the adjoining and surrounding properties. Said disability shall be established by certification of a licensed physician. (2) Any permit issued under these conditions shall be valid only for 12 months. Said permit may be renewed by request of the holder in the form of a petition requesting a one-year extension by the zoning board of appeals. Such request shall indicate a statement by a licensed physician that such medical disability continues to exist. The below-described security bond shall be renewed at such time also, unless such bond is paid by certified check. (3) The manufactured or industrial home must be placed on a tract of land which complies with the requirements of Code Section 70-63(2)(a). (4) Where the zoning ordinance permits a manufactured or industrial home to be established as a hardship use second dwelling unit on a lot with a site built single-family detached dwelling, it shall be permitted only in a rear yard. (5) No additions shall be made to any manufactured or industrial home used for hardship use. (6) The hardship use manufactured or industrial home shall be located on the tract of land in a manner consistent with the location of buildings on adjoining lots. (7) Prior to the issuance of a permit, the petitioner shall furnish a bond or certified check payable to the city in an amount determined by the building inspector as being necessary to cover the cost of moving the unit from the property if not removed as required by the hardship use permit. Said bond shall be for the expressed purpose of paying any and all costs incurred by the city in the removal and storage of the manufactured or industrial in the event of a violation of any of the provisions of these regulations. (Ord. of 9-1-05; Ord. No. 2010-11, § 3, 8-16-10) Sec. 50-84. - Procedures for approving the placement in R-A or R-2 residential zoning districts of manufactured or industrial homes possessing characteristics of site-built buildings, and meeting the compatibility standards set forth in subsection 50-80(b). (a) Applications for approval of placement of manufactured and industrial homes in R-A or R-2 residential zoning districts shall be made on a form or forms developed for that purpose and shall be submitted to the city building inspector or his designee for review and approval in accordance with this chapter. (b) Such applications shall include all information necessary to make determinations as to conformity with the provisions of this chapter as applicable to each such structure and, as applicable, conformity with the standards herein, including photographs or renderings of the front and side of the manufactured or industrial home, exterior finish, and other information necessary to make determinations required by this chapter. (c) Approval or denial of the application shall be within five days of receipt of the application and all required supporting materials. The applicant shall be notified in writing of the approval, conditional approval or denial of the application within five working days after such decision is made. Conditional approval shall require that the conditions and reasons therefor be stated in writing and be agreed to by the applicant; such conditions shall be binding upon the applicant. In the case of disapproval, the reasons therefor shall be stated in writing. (d) The city building inspector may approve deviations from the standards set forth in subparagraphs (3) and (4) of Code section on the basis of a finding that the materials to be utilized or the architectural style proposed for the dwelling unit will be compatible and harmonious to or superior to existing structures in the vicinity. (e) Appeals of the decisions of the city building inspector in interpretations, conditional grants or denial of permits shall be made to city council. The decision of the city council shall be based on the purpose and intent of the chapter provided that the spirit of the ordinance shall be observed, public welfare and safety be secured, and substantial justice done. (f) Appellate procedure to be utilized is set out in section 50-85. (Ord. of 9-1-05) Sec. 50-85. - Procedure for appeal of denial or conditional approval for placement of manufactured and industrial homes in R-A or R-2 residential zoning districts. (a) Any person aggrieved by a decision of the city building inspector or other officer, charged with the approval, conditional approval or denial of the placement of manufactured or industrial homes in R-A or R-2 residential zoning districts may appeal from such decision to the city council by filing with the clerk of said body a petition in writing setting forth plainly, fully and distinctly therein how the decision appealed from is contrary to the provisions of this chapter or the laws of this state. Such appeal shall be filed within 30 days after the date on which the decision is rendered. The date on which the decision is rendered shall be the date on which that decision is reduced to writing as required in this chapter. (b) An appeal stays all legal proceedings in furtherance of the action appealed from unless such stay would cause imminent peril to life and/or property. In such case, proceedings may be stayed by an order from the city council or upon order from a court of appropriate jurisdiction. (c) The city council shall fix the date and time certain for the hearing of the appeal and shall give notice thereof to the appealing party and the city building inspector or other official making the decision appealed from. Upon the hearing, any party to the appeal may appear in person or by agent or through an attorney. (d) The city council shall decide the appeal within two working days after the date and time of the hearing. The appeal shall be sustained upon an express finding that the action of the city building inspector or other official whose action has been appealed was based on an erroneous finding of a material fact or that he acted in an arbitrary manner. In exercising its powers, city council may reverse or affirm the decision appealed, wholly or partly, or may modify the decision or determination appealed from and to that end shall have all the powers of the official from whom the appeal was taken. (e) The city council shall consider only those matters asserted in the notice of appeal and shall consider only the record of the proceedings and matters presented to the official from whom the appeal is taken. (f) Any decision from the city council may be appealed by filing an appeal with the Superior Court of this county within 30 days after the date of the decision on appeal has been rendered in writing. The decision made by the city council shall be placed in writing and the factual basis for the decision shall be set forth in the written decision. (Ord. of 9-1-05) Sec. 50-86. - Procedures for the demolition and removal of structures unsafe or unfit for human habitation. The procedural provisions of the city's nuisance abatement ordinance shall be used as the legal process by which the city building inspector shall remedy violations of these regulations and other applicable city Code provisions. (Ord. of 9-1-05) Sec. 50-87. - Existing mobile homes. Existing mobile homes shall be considered as non-conforming under this chapter, and shall be governed by the provisions regulating these uses as set forth in the zoning ordinance of the city. Notwithstanding, no mobile home shall be imported into Garden City after ____________ , 2005, and no mobile home existing within Garden City shall be relocated to another site within the city. (Ord. of 9-1-05) Sec. 50-88. - Administration and penalties. (a) The city building inspector shall be the administrator of this chapter and shall implement, administer, and enforce the provisions of this chapter. (b) Penalties for violation. Failure to comply with any of the requirements and provisions of these regulations including a violation of conditions and safeguards established in connection with grants of special exceptions, shall constitute a violation of this chapter. Any person who violates this chapter or fails to comply with any of its requirements shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined not more than $500.00 or imprisoned for not more than 30 days, or any combination thereof, and in addition, shall pay all costs and expenses involved in the case.Each day such violation continues shall be considered a separate offense. Nothing herein contained shall prevent the city from taking such other lawful action as is necessary to prevent or remedy any violation of this chapter. (Ord. of 9-1-05) Secs. 50-89—50-99. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - BUSINESS TRAILERS
Sec. 50-100. - Definitions. For the purposes of this article, the term "trailer" shall be defined to mean a vehicle on wheels or with the wheels removed, in the nature of a house trailer or such other structure commonly known as a house trailer, office trailer, manufactured home, or mobile home. The term "trailer" shall not include modular homes. (Ord. No. 2015-10, § 1, 12-7-15) Sec. 50-101. - Finding and intent. It is of increasing concern of the city council that numerous businesses are located within the city which have no permanently erected structure but are operating and conducting their businesses in trailers and have not commenced construction of a permanent structure for the conduct of their business nor applied for a building permit for such construction. The council further recognizes that great efforts have been made by the city to encourage industrial and commercial development and to attract businesses to permanently locate within the city limits. City council finds and declares that in order to ensure the proper development of commercial and industrial zoned areas within the city and to attract and encourage commercial and industrial developments, the practice of permitting businesses to operate out of trailers should no longer be permitted since it is incompatible with the desired development of the city. Accordingly, city council finds and declares that it is necessary to enact this article so as to prevent the continued operation of businesses out of trailers located within the city limit except under those certain conditions which are specifically set forth herein. (Ord. No. 2015-10, § 1, 12-7-15) Sec. 50-102. - Trailers prohibited; exception. It shall be unlawful for any individual, corporation, business, partnership, unincorporated association or any other legal or commercial entity to place, erect, part or otherwise locate a trailer on property zoned for industrial or commercial use within the corporate limits of the city except as provided in section 50-103 and section 50-105. (Ord. No. 2015-10, § 1, 12-7-15) Sec. 50-103. - Trailers associated with construction. (a) Any general contractor, subcontractor or owner-builder may locate and use a trailer for the purpose of a use reasonably required in connection with the construction of a permanent structure upon the site where the trailer is to be located upon making written application for a permit to locate same with the building official and receiving the official's approval. (b) The owner of property upon which a permanent structure is to be constructed shall have the right to locate and use a trailer on the premises for the purposes of temporarily conducting his business during the period of time that the construction is in progress upon making written application for a permit to locate such for purposes with the building official and receiving the official's approval. (Ord. No. 2015-10, § 1, 12-7-15) Sec. 50-104. - Permit applications. (a) Any individual, corporation, partnership, unincorporated association or any other legal or commercial entity seeking to locate and use a trailer for the purposes set forth in section 50-103 shall apply for a permit to do so with the building official. Such application shall not be considered until after a building permit has been issued by the building official and no sooner than 30 days prior to the actual commencement of construction and shall include the following information: (1) The name and full address of the owner of the property. (2) The name and full address of the registered owner of the trailer that is to be used. (3) A description of the trailer. (4) A sketch of the proposed location of the trailer. (5) The proposed use of the trailer. (6) The period of time for which the applicant desires to use the trailer. (b) If the application is approved, the building official shall issue a permit to the applicant to locate and use a trailer at such location for such purposes as have been applied for and approved. (c) Any permit granted hereunder shall automatically expire in 60 days after a certificate of occupancy for the building or structure erected has been granted, but in no event shall any permit granted hereunder be valid for more than one year from the date issued. (d) Any permit issued under this article shall not be renewable or assignable. (e) Upon expiration of the permit granted hereunder, the trailer must be immediately removed from the site where it is located. (Ord. No. 2015-10, § 1, 12-7-15) Sec. 50-105. - Other permitted uses for trailers. (a) Sales office for residential development. A permit for a temporary freestanding trailer to be used as the sales office for the residential subdivision or development in which it is placed may be issued by the building official for a period of 12 months, provided that all other applicable requirements of this Code are met. Such trailer may be used for both office quarters for the construction of the development and for sales activities. No trailer permitted under this subsection as a sales office or as a combination sales office and construction office quarters shall be located on the same lot as a principal residential dwelling unit, whether such dwelling unit is under construction or completed. A permit issued under this subsection may be renewed for additional periods of 12 months until certificates of occupancy have been issued for 75 percent of the dwelling units in the subdivision or development. (b) Residence for security personnel on industrial site. A conditional use permit may be issued by city council to authorize the placement of one freestanding trailer on property zoned for industrial uses, for the purpose of providing a residence for security personnel. Such permit shall be for a period of two years, renewable for successive two-year periods as deemed necessary. In addition to any conditions city council may impose as part of the conditional use permit, such trailer shall be located at least 100 feet from any property that is zoned or used for residential purposes. The permit shall automatically terminate at such time as the principal operation at the site is discontinued. (Ord. No. 2015-10, § 1, 12-7-15) Sec. 50-106. - Removal of existing trailers. Any trailers presently located and/or being used on property zoned for industrial or commercial use within the city which were located and/or being used prior to the enactment of (date of this article), shall not be affected by the terms of this article except where such trailers have fallen into such a state of deterioration as to render them a nuisance which is unfit or unsafe for use, under which circumstance the city shall have the right to order such trailers removed. (Ord. No. 2015-10, § 1, 12-7-15) Sec. 50-107. - Criminal penalties. It shall be unlawful for any individual or any officer of any firm or corporation to fail to comply with the requirements and provisions of this article and nay person who knowingly fails or refuses to comply with or willfully violates any provisions herein shall, upon conviction of such offense, be punished by a fine not to exceed $500.00. The penalties herein provided shall extend to both the actual violator and to the person causing, directing or permitting such violation. Each day of continued violation shall be considered as a separate offense and shall be punishable as such. (Ord. No. 2015-10, § 1, 12-7-15) Sec. 50-108. - Sanitary facilities. Where sanitary facilities may be involved or required in the use of the trailers as provided in this article, no permit shall be granted except upon compliance with all requirements of the county health department and of all ordinances, rules and regulations of the county and of the city governing sanitary facilities. (Ord. No. 2015-10, § 1, 12-7-15) Sec. 50-109. - Appeals from decisions of building official. (a) Any person aggrieved by any decision of the building official made under this article with respect to the granting or denial of a trailer permit may appeal such decision to city manager within 15 days after the date of such decision, requesting the city manager to review same. (b) Any person aggrieved by any action of the city manager with regard to the granting, denial or granting with limitations, restrictions or conditions of any permit may seek judicial review as provided for by the laws of the state. (Ord. No. 2015-10, § 1, 12-7-15)

div.head: Chapter 54 - MUNICIPAL COURT[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Charter reference— Municipal court, § 4.10 et seq. Cross reference— Uniform notice procedure, § 2-296 et seq.; law enforcement, ch. 46; offenses, ch. 58; traffic and vehicles, ch. 78; vehicles for hire, ch. 86. State Law reference— Establishment and jurisdiction of municipal courts, Ga. Const. art. 6, sec. 1, par. 1; municipal courts, O.C.G.A. § 36-32-1 et seq.
Sec. 54-1. - Clerk. The chief of police shall appoint a clerk of the municipal court who shall be charged with the responsibility of maintaining all records and securing all equipment necessary for the administration of the court and for the issuing of necessary subpoenas and other papers. (Code 1976, § 9-1001) Sec. 54-2. - Duties of police. The chief of police and police officers shall be vested with the responsibility of maintaining order in the court and serving all papers directed to them by the municipal court judge, the municipal court judge pro tem and the clerk. (Code 1976, § 9-1002) Sec. 54-3. - Acting judge. In the event of the absence, incapacity or disqualification of the municipal court judge or municipal court judge pro tem, upon the request of either the municipal court judge, mayor or mayor pro tem, the municipal court judge or municipal court judge pro tem of any other municipality in the county, as well as the judge or judge pro tem of the municipal court of the county, or a member of the state bar in good standing, may be authorized by either the municipal court judge, mayor or mayor pro tem to temporarily exercise the duties of the municipal court judge of the city as judge pro tem. (Code 1976, § 9-1006; Ord. of 12-6-93, § 1; Ord. of 10-3-94, § 1) Sec. 54-4. - Convening. The municipal court shall be held at such times as called by the municipal court judge. (Code 1976, § 9-1005) Sec. 54-5. - Subpoenas. Upon information or complaint lodged with any member of the police force of the city or with the clerk, any person within the limits of the city charged with the violation of any ordinance of the city, or of any law of the state, may be brought before the municipal court to answer such charge, by the service upon such a person of a subpoena from the court setting forth the nature of the charge and the time of the hearing, and the municipal court judge or other presiding officer of the court shall have the power to punish any person disobeying such a subpoena, within the limits of punishment prescribed in section 1-13. Any person desired as witness in any case or charge pending in the court may be compelled to attend any session of the court by service upon such person, at any place within the limits of the city, of a subpoena from the court setting forth the name of the case and the time of the hearing, and the municipal court judge or other presiding officer of such court shall have the power to punish any person failing or refusing to obey such subpoena, within the limits of punishment prescribed in section 1-13. (Code 1976, § 9-1004) Sec. 54-6. - Sentencing of offenders. (a) The city authorities shall have the power to contract with the county authorities to maintain a jail to which persons convicted in the municipal court may be sent to be confined and to labor during the term of their sentences. (b) The municipal court judge or other presiding officer of the municipal court is hereby authorized to send to the jail persons convicted in the court to be there confined and to labor during the terms of sentence. (c) When not sent to the county jail, persons given jail sentences in the municipal court shall work out such sentence in any public works or on the streets, roads, drains and squares in the city. (Code 1976, § 9-1003)

div.head: Chapter 58 - OFFENSES[1]
Chapter 60 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Parks and recreation board, § 2-136 et seq.; alcoholic beverages, ch. 6; businesses, ch. 22; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 66.
Sec. 60-1. - Purpose. The purpose of this chapter is to provide rules and regulations for the use of and conduct in the parks and recreation areas of the city. (Ord. of 8-19-96(3), § 1) Sec. 60-2. - Applicability. This chapter shall apply in all parks and recreation areas under the jurisdiction of the city, unless expressly exempted. For the issuance of permits, authorizations, granting of approvals, and other actions, the approving agency shall be the recreation commission. (Ord. of 8-19-96(3), § 2) Sec. 60-3. - Definitions. As used in this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings indicated: Animals means cats, dogs, horses, any fowl or birds and any living creatures within the jurisdiction of the parks or recreation areas. Approving agency means the recreation commission. Permit means any written license issued by or under the authority of the approving agency permitting a special event or activity on park facilities. Person means any natural person, corporation, company, association, joint stock association, firm or co-partnership. (Ord. of 8-19-96(3), § 3) Sec. 60-4. - Structures; plants; trees; earth; rubbish. It shall be unlawful for any person in a public park or recreation area to: (1) Mark, deface, disfigure, injure, tamper with or displace or remove any buildings, tables, benches, railings, pavings or paving materials, water lines or other public utilities or parts or appurtenances thereof, signs, notices or placards, whether temporary or permanent, monuments, stakes, posts, or other boundary markers, or other structures or equipment, facilities or park property or appurtenances whatsoever, either real or personal. (2) Fail to cooperate in maintaining restrooms and washrooms in a neat and sanitary condition. No person over the age of six years shall use the restrooms and washrooms designated for the opposite sex. (3) Dig or remove any soil, rock, sand, stones, trees, shrubs or plants or other wood or materials. (4) Construct or erect any building or structure of whatever kind, whether permanent or temporary, or run or string any public service utility into, upon, or across such lands, except on special written permit issued hereunder. (5) Damage, cut, carve, mark, transplant or remove any plant, or injure the bark of any tree, dig in or otherwise disturb grass areas, or in any other way injure the natural beauty or usefulness of any area. (6) Climb any tree; climb, stand or sit upon property not designated or customarily used for such purpose. (7) Attach any rope or cable or other contrivance to any tree, fence, railing, bench, or other structure. (8) Take into, carry through, or put into any park, any rubbish, refuse, garbage or other material. Such refuse and rubbish shall be deposited in receptacles so provided. Where receptacles are not provided, all such rubbish or waste shall be carried away from the park by the person responsible for its presence, and properly disposed of elsewhere. (Ord. of 8-19-96(3), § 4) Sec. 60-5. - Firearms; weapons; tools. It shall be unlawful for any person to bring into or have in his possession in any park or recreation area: (1) Any pistol or revolver or objects upon which loaded or blank cartridges may be used. Official starters, at authorized track and field events, are excepted from this restriction. (2) Any burglar tools. (3) Any rifle, shotgun, BB gun, air gun, spring gun, slingshot, bow, or other weapon in which the propelling force is gunpowder, a spring or air. (Ord. of 8-19-96(3), § 5) Sec. 60-6. - Explosives and fireworks. It shall be unlawful for any person to have in his possession or set off any fireworks. Permits may be given for conducting properly supervised fireworks in designated park areas. (Ord. of 8-19-96(3), § 6) Sec. 60-7. - Advertising; assemblages; entertainment. (a) No person shall post, paint, affix, distribute, deliver, place, cast or leave about, any bill, billboard, placard, ticket, handbill, circular, or advertisement. (b) No person shall do any of the following without a permit, provided that no permit shall be required for any action or event sponsored by the city or the recreation commission: (1) Display any advertising signs or other advertising matter, provided that a sign attached to a vehicle to identify the vehicle, or a sign lawfully on a taxi or bus, is not prohibited. (2) Operate for advertising purposes any musical instrument, soundtrack or drum. (3) Hold public assemblages. (4) Conduct exhibitions. (5) Hold a parade. (Ord. of 8-19-96(3), § 7) Sec. 60-8. - Flea market sales prohibited. No lawn sales, attic sales, rummage sales, flea market sales, or any similar casual sales of tangible personal property shall be permitted in any park or recreation area. (Ord. of 8-19-96(3), § 8) Sec. 60-9. - Ignitable and combustible materials. No person shall kindle, build, maintain or use a fire except in places provided for such purposes. Any fire shall be continuously under the care and direction of a competent person from the time it is kindled until it is extinguished. (Ord. of 8-19-96(3), § 9) Sec. 60-10. - Alcoholic beverages; controlled dangerous substances; alms; gambling. While in a public park or recreation area, all persons shall conduct themselves in a proper and orderly manner, and in particular, no person shall: (1) Bring alcoholic beverages, or controlled dangerous substances, drink or use the same at any time nor shall any person be under the influence of intoxicating liquor or a controlled dangerous substance in a park or recreation area. (2) Solicit alms or contributions for any purpose, whether public or private. (3) Play any game of chance or have possession of any instrument or device for gambling. (4) Play, engage or take part in any game or competitive sport for money, or other valuable thing, without a written permit. (Ord. of 8-19-96(3), § 10) Sec. 60-11. - Miscellaneous conduct. It shall be unlawful for any person in a park or recreation area to: (1) Camp or stay overnight. (2) Take part in the playing of any games involving thrown or otherwise propelled objects except in those areas designated for such forms of recreation. (3) Play football, baseball, basketball, soccer or lacrosse, except in areas designated for such games. (4) Roller skate or use skateboards except in those areas specifically designed for such pastimes. (5) Enter an area posted as "closed to the public." (6) Engage in threatening, abusive, insulting or indecent language or engage in any disorderly conduct or behavior tending to breach the public peace. (7) Fail to produce and exhibit any permit he claims to have, upon request of any authorized person who shall desire to inspect the same for the purpose of enforcing compliance with any ordinance or rule. (8) Disturb or interfere unreasonably with any person or party occupying any area or participating in any activity under the authority of a permit. (Ord. of 8-19-96(3), § 11) Sec. 60-12. - Closing hours. Except for designated camping areas, no person shall be in any park during the hours the park is closed. All parks are closed from 11:00 p.m. to 6:00 a.m. (Ord. of 8-19-96(3), § 12) Sec. 60-13. - Regulated activities. The following activities are permitted only at times and in areas so designated for that purpose and are prohibited elsewhere within the parks: (1) Swimming, bathing, wading, fishing. (2) Model airplane flying. (3) Baseball. (4) Tennis. (5) Picnicking. (6) Football and track. (7) Basketball. (8) Soccer. (9) Bicycle riding. (10) Throwing or propelling any objects. (11) Roller skating. (Ord. of 8-19-96(3), § 13) Sec. 60-14. - Permits. (a) Application procedure. Permits for special events in parks and recreation areas shall be obtained by application to the approving commissioners in accordance with the following procedure: (1) A person seeking issuance of a permit hereunder shall file an application stating: a. The name and address of the applicant. b. The name and address of the person, persons, corporation or association sponsoring the activity, if any. c. The day and hours for which the permit is desired. d. The park or portion thereof for which the permit is desired. e. Any other information reasonably necessary to a determination as to whether a permit should be issued hereunder. f. Variances required from park rules and regulations. (2) Standards for issuance of a use permit shall include the following findings: a. That the proposed activity or use of the park will not unreasonably interfere with or detract from the general public's enjoyment of the park. b. That the proposed activity and use will not unreasonably interfere with or detract from the promotion of public health, welfare, safety and recreation. c. That the proposed activity or uses that are reasonably anticipated will not include violence, crime or disorderly conduct. d. That the proposed activity will not entail extraordinary or burdensome expense or police operation by the city. e. That the facilities desired have not been reserved for other use on the date and hour requested in the application. (b) Appeal. (1) Within ten days after the receipt of an application, the recreation commission shall tell an applicant in writing of its decision to grant or deny a permit; in the event of a denial, the notification shall include the reason for the denial. Any aggrieved person shall have the right to appeal to the city council by serving written notice thereof on the city administrator within five working days of said refusal. (2) A copy of said notice shall also be served on the recreation commission within the same time and said commission shall immediately forward the application and the reasons for its refusal to the city council. The city council shall decide within ten days from the receipt of the appeal by the city administrator, or at its first meeting after the appeal, whichever is later. The decision of the city council shall be final. (c) Park rules and regulations. A permittee shall be bound by all park rules and regulations and all applicable ordinances fully as though the same were inserted in said permits. (d) Insurance. An applicant for a permit may be required to submit evidence of liability insurance covering injuries to members of the general public arising out of such permitted activities in such amounts as may be from time to time determined prior to the commencement of any activity or issuance of any permit. (e) Revocation. The city council shall have the authority to revoke a permit upon a finding of violation of any rule or ordinance or upon good cause shown. (Ord. of 8-19-96(3), § 14) Sec. 60-15. - Enforcement. (a) The city police department, recreation commission, and their respective agents, shall, in connection with their duties imposed by law, diligently enforce the provisions of this chapter. (b) The city police department shall have the authority to order any person or persons acting in violation of this chapter to leave the park or recreation area. (Ord. of 8-19-96(3), § 15) Sec. 60-16. - Penalty. Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this chapter shall be fined not less than $50.00 nor more than $500.00 for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. (Ord. of 8-19-96(3), § 16) Sec. 60-17. - Construction. In the interpretation of this and all succeeding park and recreation area ordinances, the provisions shall be construed as follows: (1) No provision hereof shall make unlawful any act necessarily performed by any officer or employee of the commission or city in line of duty or work as such, or by any person, his agent or employees, in the proper and necessary execution of the terms of any agreement with the commission or city. (2) Any act otherwise prohibited by law or local ordinance shall be lawful if performed, under, by virtue of, and strictly within the provisions of a permit so to do, and to the extent authorized thereby. (Ord. of 8-19-96(3), § 17)

div.head: Chapter 62 - SOLID WASTE[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; businesses, ch. 22; environment, ch. 30; health and sanitation, ch. 42; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 66; utilities, ch. 82. State Law reference— Authorization to provide garbage and solid waste collection and disposal, Ga. Const. art. 9, sec. 2, par. 3; Solid Waste Management Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-20 et seq.; local and regional solid waste plans, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-31.1; hazardous waste disposal, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-61 et seq.; Litter Control Law, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-40; transporting garbage or waste across state or county boundaries pursuant to contract, O.C.G.A. § 36-1-16; Resource Recovery Development Authorities Law, O.C.G.A. § 36-63-1 et seq.; littering highways, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-249.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 62-1. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Ashes, cinders and clinkers. The term "ashes" means the residue from the burning of wood, coal, coke and other combustible material in homes, stores, institutions and small commercial establishments and industrial plants, which is produced as the result of heating, cooking, and disposing of waste combustible material. The terms "cinders" and "clinkers" include large residue from the burning of coal and coke as produced from larger furnaces such as steam generator plants or large heating furnaces. Biomedical waste means pathological waste, biological waste cultures and stocks of infectious agents and associated biologicals, contaminated animal carcasses (body parts, their bedding, and other wastes from such animals), sharps, chemotherapy waste, discarded medical equipment and parts, not including expendable supplies and materials which have not been decontaminated, as further defined in Rule 391-3-4.15 of the Georgia Board of Natural Resources, and other such waste materials. Building rubbish means waste material resulting from construction, remodeling, repairs and demolition operations on houses, commercial buildings and other structures, including driveways and walks, and it comprises waste and rejected matter such as excavated earth, stones, bricks, plaster, wallpaper, sheetrock and laths, lumber, shingles, tile, concrete and waste parts occasioned by the installation or replacement of plumbing, heating systems, electrical work and roofing. Combustible rubbish means any burnable materials such as paper, rags, cartons, cardboard and wooden boxes, wood, excelsior, furniture, bedding, leather, rubber, tree branches, yard trimmings, sawdust, leaves, linoleum, plastics and the like. Dead animal means the carcass of any small animal such as a dog, cat, squirrel, opossum, rabbit, rat, reptile, fowl, bird or any other such animal of this size. Garbage means the animal and vegetable waste resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and serving of foods, being composed largely of putrescible organic matter and its natural moisture content, originating primarily in home kitchens, stores, markets, restaurants, hotels, hospitals or other places where food is stored, prepared or served. Hazardous waste means any solid waste which has been defined as a hazardous waste in regulations promulgated by the administrator of the United States Environmental Protection Agency pursuant to the federal Solid Waste Disposal Act, as amended, particularly by the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act of 1976 (Public Law 94-580, 42 U.S.C. 6901, et. seq.), as amended, particularly by but not limited to the Used Oil Recycling Act of 1980 (Public Law 96-463), the Solid Waste Disposal Act Amendments of 1980 (Public Law 96-482), the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 (Public Law 96-510), the Hazardous and Solid Waste Amendments of 1984 (Public Law 98-616), and the Superfund Amendments and Reauthorization Act of 1986 (Public Law 99-499), as amended, which are in force and effect on February 1, 1996, codified as 40 CFR § 261.3 and any designated hazardous waste. Household sharp medical waste means any type of product capable of puncturing or lacerating the skin that is designed or used to treat, diagnose, or prevent a disease or medical condition, including, but not limited to, scalpels and hypodermic needles. Industrial refuse means solid waste materials from factories, processing plants, wholesale establishments, assembling plants or shops and garages, such as paper, cardboard, cartons, food processing wastes, cinders and ashes, lumber scraps, sawdust, excelsior, shavings, floor sweepings, metal scrap and shavings, glass and other waste products. Leachate collection system means a system for collection of the leachate which may percolate through the waste and into the soils surrounding a facility the primary purpose of which is the storage, collection, transportation, treatment, utilization, processing, or disposal, or any combination thereof, of solid waste. Noncombustible rubbish means materials such as metals, tin cans, metal furniture, dirt, glass, crockery, ashes and cinders and mineral matter that will not burn at 2,000 degrees Fahrenheit. Recyclable materials means all glass, tin, aluminum, cardboard, paper and other materials that can be processed for reuse. Refuse means all classifications of solid waste. Roll-out cart and garbage roll-out cart mean a plastic 80-gallon container, furnished by the city, which has a lid and wheels to roll on. A roll-out cart may be referred to as a cart or receptacle. Rubbish comprises combustible rubbish and noncombustible rubbish. Sharps container means a container specifically manufactured for the disposal of sharp medical waste. Sludge includes the accumulated solid, residues, and precipitates generated as a result of waste treatment or processing, including wastewater treatment, water supply treatment, or operation of an air pollution control facility, and mixed liquids and solids pumped from septic tanks, grease traps, privies, or similar waste disposal appurtenances. Solid waste means any garbage or refuse; sludge from a wastewater treatment plant, water supply treatment plant, or air pollution control facility; and other discarded material including solid, semisolid, or contained gaseous material resulting from industrial, commercial, mining, and agricultural operations and community activities, but does not include recovered materials; solid or dissolved materials in domestic sewage; solid or dissolved materials in irrigation return flows or industrial discharges that are point sources subject to permit under 33 U.S.C. 1342; or source, special nuclear, or by-product material as defined by the federal Atomic Energy Act of 1954, as amended (68 Stat. 923). Solid waste transfer station means an intermediate waste facility in which solid waste collected from any source is temporarily deposited to await transportation to the final disposal site or facility. Street refuse includes both combustible and noncombustible materials such as street sweepings, dirt, leaves, catchbasin collections, grass trimmings, contents of litter receptacles and glass. Yard rubbish means tree branches, stumps, twigs, grass and shrub trimmings, bushes, weeds, leaves and general yard and garden waste materials, and includes stone and dirt rakings and any waste materials resulting from landscaping. (Code 1976, §§ 4-2001, 4-2007; Ord. of 11-17-97, § 1; Ord. of 5-4-98(1), § 1) Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. Sec. 62-2. - Authority to prescribe additional rules and regulations. The superintendent of sanitation, subject to the approval of the mayor, shall have the authority to establish rules and regulations, consistent with the provisions of this chapter, governing the keeping, collection, removal and disposal of garbage and refuse. It shall be unlawful for any person to fail, neglect or refuse to comply with such rules and regulations. (Code 1976, § 4-2002) Sec. 62-3. - Unauthorized collection prohibited. No person other than a person under the direction of the superintendent of sanitation or a person otherwise authorized by the city shall haul away any garbage and refuse set out for collection by the sanitation department. (Code 1976, § 4-2003) Sec. 62-4. - Collection or transport of combustible refuse. No person shall engage in the collection or transportation of combustible refuse matter without having applied for permission therefor and received the approval of the mayor in the form of a written permit. Every person obtaining such permission shall conform to the rules of the department of sanitation. Upon violation of the rules, such permit shall be revoked by the mayor. (Code 1976, § 4-2004) Secs. 62-5—62-25. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - RECEPTACLES DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 62-26. - Use required; unlawful deposit of waste. (a) Throwing waste on street or sidewalk. It shall be unlawful for any person to place or throw waste paper, trash, waste material or garbage on any street, sidewalk or alley of the city. (b) Deposit of waste generally. It shall be unlawful to deposit garbage, trash or waste material upon any vacant or unoccupied premises or any public property within the city, and no garbage, trash or waste material shall be placed on any private property except in garbage containers specifically provided therefor. (c) Unsecured waste prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any property owner or tenant or other person to permit garbage, waste materials, trash, paper, paper cups or food containers of any kind to remain unsecured on his property. Such materials shall be placed in a closed, approved garbage container immediately after use. (Code 1976, § 4-2006) Sec. 62-27. - Interference with receptacles. No person shall overturn or otherwise interfere with the contents of any receptacle set out for removal by the city. (Code 1976, § 4-2037) Secs. 62-28—62-40. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - ROLL-OUT CARTS
Sec. 62-41. - Furnishing by city. The city shall furnish to each owner or lessee of a residence or apartment within the city an 80-gallon roll-out cart. Any owner or lessee shall be allowed to purchase, at his expense, an additional roll-out cart at the city's cost. The cart will be delivered after the resident or tenant furnishes either a utility deposit as required in section 82-171, or, if only sanitation services are provided, a sanitation deposit as required by subsection 62-141(a). (Code 1976, § 4-2008; Ord. of 1-19-87, § 1) Sec. 62-42. - Serial number; assignment; agreement by persons receiving carts. A roll-out cart furnished by the city shall be stamped with the name of the city and a serial number and shall be assigned to an address and to the owner or lessee at such address. Under no circumstances shall a roll-out cart be removed from the premises. The owner or lessee shall, for each roll-out cart furnished by the city, agree to the following in writing: Roll-out Garbage Cart Serial Number ____________ . The undersigned hereby acknowledges the receipt of one roll-out garbage cart supplied by the City of Garden City for the use of the resident at the below-stated address. Further, the undersigned agrees to pay for the replacement of the roll-out garbage cart should it be lost or stolen and to pay for the cost of any repairs to the roll-out cart made necessary because of abuse or negligence. The city will pay for all repairs to the roll-out cart caused by normal wear and tear. The undersigned acknowledges receipt of a copy of the City of Garden City regulations governing the collection and disposal of solid waste material. The undersigned is the (owner) (lessee) (check one) of the below address. The undersigned must be one or the other. The undersigned further acknowledges his responsibility and liability should the cart be lost or stolen or damaged as stated herein.
(Code 1976, § 4-2009) Sec. 62-43. - Ownership. The city shall retain ownership of roll-out carts which are provided to residences for garbage collection. Such carts shall not be removed from the premises. (Code 1976, § 4-2010) Sec. 62-44. - Marking of name or address. Where more than one family occupies a dwelling or an apartment, the roll-out cart shall be so marked as to indicate the family using the particular garbage cart. The cart may be identified by putting the apartment number thereon or the name of the persons having control of the disposal of garbage in the household. When carts are so identified, such cart may be used only by the person whose name or other identification is shown thereon. (Code 1976, § 4-2011) Sec. 62-45. - Report of stolen or damaged carts. If a roll-out cart is stolen or damaged, this fact should be reported within 48 hours to the city. (Code 1976, § 4-2012) Sec. 62-46. - Replacement of lost, stolen or damaged carts. Any residential roll-out cart provided by the city which becomes lost or stolen shall be replaced by the city and shall be paid for by the owner or lessee of the residence to which the cart is assigned. Carts which are damaged through normal use shall be repaired or replaced by the city. Carts which are damaged through no fault of the city shall be replaced by the city and paid for by the owner or lessee of the residence to which the cart is assigned. (Code 1976, § 4-2013) Sec. 62-47. - Notification of moving; reclamation of cart by city. If an owner or lessee moves from the residence to which a roll-out cart has been assigned, such owner or lessee shall notify the superintendent of sanitation at least two days prior to moving and the cart will be reclaimed by the city. (Code 1976, § 4-2014) Sec. 62-48. - Deposit of garbage. All garbage shall be deposited daily in the roll-out cart provided by the city. The cart shall be kept closed to keep out water and animals and to comply with state health and sanitation regulations. (Code 1976, § 4-2015) Sec. 62-49. - Time and location of placement for collection. Roll-out carts provided to residences by the city as provided in this division shall be placed near the curb, or near the street, but not in the street, or in such other accessible place approved by the superintendent of sanitation. Carts shall be placed in such location no earlier than 5:00 p.m. one day prior to the date of collection, and shall be removed no later than 7:00 p.m. on the date of collection. The superintendent of sanitation shall provide a schedule to each residence receiving garbage collection service from the carts from the city, which shall indicate the days on which such collection will be made. Any person who is physically unable to place the garbage roll-out cart at the curb or near the street by reason of physical limitations shall be excused from doing so by submitting a written request to the superintendent of sanitation setting forth such physical limitations and receiving permission from the superintendent to be excluded from placing the cart at the curb or near the street. Customers should make suitable arrangements with neighbors or friends to set out and remove their roll-out carts from the curbside if absent during the hours specified herein. A customer allowing a container to remain at curbside outside the hours specified herein shall be deemed to create a nuisance. Accordingly, containers observed to be on the street at times not allowed shall be removed by employees or designated agents of the city's solid waste collection provider and placed near the front edge of the residence or near the garage area. A tag shall be left on the cart handle explaining the infraction and service performed. A fee as stated in the city's rate schedule for the service will be charged to the monthly utility bill. (Code 1976, § 4-2016; Ord. No. 2010-13, § 1, 10-4-10; Ord. No. 2014-4, §§ 1, 2, 5-19-14; Ord. No. 2014-5, §§ 1, 2, 6-16-14) Secs. 62-50—62-60. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - BULK CONTAINERS
Sec. 62-61. - Required containers for townhouses and apartments. Owners of townhouse developments and owners of residential apartment buildings, or of a group of residence apartment buildings in the same complex wherein there are more than four living units either in a single building or in the complex treated as a unit, are hereby required to install and maintain for each townhouse development and for each residence apartment building which contains more than four living units, and for each residence apartment group or complex which group or complex contains in the aggregate more than four living units, stationary bulk refuse containers according to the following specifications: (1) A stationary bulk refuse container with a minimum capacity of four cubic yards is required for each townhouse development and for each residence apartment building which contains more than four and less than 13 living units, and for each residence apartment group or complex which group or complex contains in the aggregate more than four and less than 13 living units. (2) A stationary bulk refuse container with a minimum capacity of six cubic yards is required for each townhouse development and for each residence apartment building which contains more than 12 and less than 17 living units, and for each residence apartment group or complex which group or complex contains in the aggregate more than 12 and less than 17 living units. (3) A stationary bulk refuse container with a minimum capacity of eight cubic yards is required for each townhouse development and for each residence apartment building which contains more than 16 and less than 31 living units, and for each residence apartment group or complex which group or complex contains in the aggregate more than 16 and less than 31 living units. (4) Where a townhouse development or a residence apartment building or a residence apartment group or complex contains in excess of 30 living units, additional stationary bulk refuse containers are required to be installed and maintained as a minimum in the same ratio as set forth in subsections (1), (2) and (3) of this section for the living units in excess of 30. (5) The provisions of this section notwithstanding, a developer of a townhouse development having a ground floor entrance and living area may elect, at the time of site plan approval, to have such development served by individual containers at each dwelling unit rather than by stationary bulk containers. The developer shall indicate any such election by means of a notation on the required site plan for the development. The location of individual containers to be provided pursuant to such election shall be subject to the approval of the mayor or his designee, who shall determine, as a condition of approving the location of such individual containers, that all such individual containers are: a. At ground level; b. Located in such a manner as to provide reasonable accessibility to refuse collectors; and c. Located, with respect to buildings and roadways, in such a manner as to afford the most reasonably short distance from the nearest roadway to the container. For the purposes of this subsection, a developer of a townhouse development shall include an owner of a multifamily dwelling who proposes to develop or sell such multifamily dwelling as individually owned townhouses. A developer of a townhouse development whose site plans have already been approved shall have 90 days from the effective date of the ordinance from which this section derives to make the election set forth in this subsection (5). (Code 1976, § 4-2017(a)) Sec. 62-62. - Required containers for businesses. Businesses are required to store their waste matter in either roll-out containers (regulation receptacles) or the city-prescribed metal bulk waste containers. The metal bulk containers are optional if a business has no more than three regulation receptacles. If the waste accumulated between collections exceeds three regulation receptacles, the business must purchase and maintain a prescribed bulk container. The size of the container and its location are to be prescribed by the superintendent of sanitation. If a business's waste exceeds the capacity of one bulk container, the business must purchase an additional container. (Code 1976, § 4-2017(b); Ord. of 6-5-95, § 2) Sec. 62-63. - Location. The location of required stationary bulk refuse containers shall be such as to permit convenient and safe access by the servicing truck and equipment using all-weather streets or alleys of adequate strength, to minimize as far as reasonably permitted excessive walking distances for tenants and occupants, and to be as aesthetically pleasing as the circumstances will reasonably allow, in order to conveniently permit servicing of such stationary bulk refuse containers upon a collection schedule of twice per week. (Code 1976, § 4-2018) Sec. 62-64. - Emptying of containers near residential districts prohibited during certain hours. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to pick up or empty bulk refuse containers at businesses located in a C-1 and C-2 zoning classification lying adjacent to and abutting an R-1 residential zoning classification during the hours from 10:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m. (b) A person convicted of a violation of this section shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-13. (Ord. of 11-19-90, §§ 1, 2) Sec. 62-65. - Bulk container and dumpster areas. (a) All bulk containers and dumpsters in commercial zoning districts shall be located and designed so as not to be visible from the view of adjacent streets and properties. If the bulk container or dumpster is not visible from off the site, then it need not be screened. If the bulk container or dumpster is visible from off the site, screening is required in accordance with the following standards: (1) The screen shall be at least as high as the highest point of the bulk container or dumpster. (2) The screen shall be made of a material that is opaque at the time of installation and compatible with the design and materials of the principal building. (3) The screening shall contain gates to allow for access to the container and security. (4) The screening shall completely enclose the bulk container or dumpster so as to retain windblown litter. (5) The dumpster or bulk container must be accessible to the handicapped. (b) All bulk containers and dumpsters existing upon the effective date of this section (April 19, 1999), which do not meet the screening requirements as provided for herein shall be altered to comply with these provisions within ninety days of said date. A variance may be granted in the manner provided for by this chapter to grant a time extension in specific instances for compliance with the provisions of this section. Such variance shall only be granted if the applicant can demonstrate that: (1) The granting of a time extension will not be detrimental to persons or property in the neighborhood. (2) The granting of a time extension is not contrary to the intent of this section. (3) The granting of a time extension will alleviate a hardship on the applicant. (c) Variances in general. The board of appeals shall be authorized to grant general variances to the screening requirements of this section. (Ord. of 4-19-99(1), § 1) Secs. 62-66—62-85. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - PREPARATION AND PLACEMENT FOR COLLECTION
Sec. 62-86. - Wrapping and draining of garbage; materials permitted in receptacles. All garbage placed in receptacles shall be wrapped and shall be drained and free of dishwater, and no liquids, except the natural moisture content of garbage, shall be placed in receptacles. Combustible refuse such as paper, cardboard, rags, grass trimmings and small tin cans and glass bottles may be placed in garbage receptacles. (Code 1976, § 4-2021) Sec. 62-87. - Placement of leaves in receptacles. Subject to section 62-89, leaves shall not be placed in receptacles. (Code 1976, § 4-2022) Sec. 62-88. - Separate container required for certain materials. Separate receptacles shall be provided for ashes, glass, floor sweepings and other incombustibles, and for recyclable materials. (Code 1976, § 4-2023) Sec. 62-89. - Preparation and storage of trash and large objects. (a) Property owners or occupants shall be required to prepare and store trash for collection in the following manner: (1) Leaves, yard clippings, paper, straw and other small or flexible objects shall be placed in approved watertight containers. Approved containers shall include standard paper or plastic bags manufactured for refuse disposal, or other suitable containers which, when full, do not exceed 50 pounds in weight. (2) Subject to section 62-90, discarded tree branches, heavy brush, furniture, appliances and other large objects which cannot be placed in containers shall be stored or stacked in a neat and orderly manner until arrangements for special unscheduled collection by the city or other means of disposal have been made by the property owner. (b) Where collection service is provided from a public lane or alley, property owners shall place trash containers and bundles at the rear property line. Placement shall be made in a manner which does not create an obstruction to refuse collection and other vehicles which use the lane or alley. Offsets in fences, walls and hedges shall be provided, when necessary, to prevent such obstructions. (c) Where collection service is provided from a street, trash containers and bundles shall be placed in front of the property, adjacent to the road right-of-way. Placement shall be made in a manner which does not create an obstruction to pedestrian or vehicular traffic or interfere with roadside ditches. (d) Property owners and occupants are responsible for maintaining in a neat and orderly manner trash containers and bundles prepared and stored in accordance with the provisions of this section until collection is made. (Code 1976, § 4-2024) Sec. 62-90. - Size of tree and shrub trimmings. Tree and shrub trimmings shall not exceed four feet in length and 18 inches in diameter. (Code 1976, § 4-2025; Ord. of 12-2-85, § 1) Sec. 62-91. - Noncontainerized trash. (a) Any trash or debris which has not been containerized, bundled or stored in accordance with the provisions of this article shall be prohibited unless arrangements for special collection by the city or other means of disposal have been made. (b) No such trash or debris shall be placed in the public right-of-way, and all owners and occupants shall be responsible for the removal and storage of such trash or debris as provided in this article. (Code 1976, § 4-2028) Sec. 62-92. - Enforcement, violations and penalties.
