(a) If items of solid waste are placed for collection by a resident or business in violation of article III, article IV, or article VII of this chapter 62 by virtue of such items not being of the type collected by the city as provided herein or not being prepared or stored in compliance with the terms of this chapter, the city may cause such items to be removed and the owner of such premises will be liable for the cost to the city for such removal, including but not limited to employee and equipment costs, disposal costs, including the cost of any bags, which should have been used with respect to such items for collection, together with an administrative fee of $75.00. The city may, but shall not be required to, notify the owner of the premises of such violation and may, but shall not be required to, give the owner an opportunity to correct the violation. However, if notice of the violation is not given prior to the city's removing or having such items removed and assessing the costs in accordance with this section, the owner shall be given notice that the city has removed such items and of the assessed costs which shall be included on the owner's next utility bill. Such owner shall appeal such charge in writing with the director of public works. Using the information provided by the appellant, the director shall conduct a review of the circumstances surrounding the solid waste ordinance violation and respond to the appeal in writing within 30 days. If, among other grounds, it is determined by the director that neither the owner nor anyone who occupied the premises was responsible for the placement of such items or the failure to remove such items, he may waive such costs assessed against such property owner. A decision of the director to which is adverse to an appellant may be further appealed to the city manager within 30 days of receipt of notice of the adverse decision. Notice of the appeal shall be served on the city manager by the appellant, stating the grounds for the appeal. The city manager shall issue a written decision on the appeal within 30 days. All decisions of the city manager shall be served on the appellant personally or by registered or certified mail, sent to the billing address of the appellant. All decisions of the city manager shall be final. (b) Remedy not exclusive. The remedy listed above is not exclusive of any other remedy available under any applicable state or local law and the city may seek cumulative remedies (c) Each day any violation of any provision of article III, article IV, or article VII of this chapter exists shall constitute a separate offense. (d) In addition to any other penalty or sanction imposed in this section 62-92, a violation of any provision of article III, article IV, or article VII, pertaining to the preparation and placement of solid waste for collection shall also constitute a municipal civil infraction subject to the penalties in Code section 1-13. (Ord. No. 2012-13, § 1, 12-3-12) Secs. 62-93—62-100. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - COLLECTION SERVICE

No owner of a residential property shall be exempt or relieved from payment of the sanitation and handling fee by reason of failure or refusal to receive services provided the city. Such fee shall be imposed against the property itself and payment of the fee shall be enforceable and collected as provided by law for levy and sale of in rem liens. (Ord. No. 2010-4, § 1, 3-1-10) Editor's note— Ord. No. 2010-4, § 1, adopted March 1, 2010, repealed former § 62-111, and enacted a new § 62-111 as set out herein. (Code 1976, § 4-2034) Sec. 62-118. - City not to be responsible for articles used as containers. (Code 1976, § 4-2036.1) Sec. 62-120. - Removal of receptacles from street. No garbage or other refuse receptacle of any kind shall remain upon any public street or sidewalk. (Code 1976, § 4-2036) Sec. 62-121. - Reserved. Editor's note— Ord. No. 2009-9, § 2, adopted Aug. 17, 2009, deleted § 62-121, which pertained to disposition of recyclable materials. See the Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. Sec. 62-122. - Disposition of sharp medical waste from households. Household sharp medical waste shall not be deposited in any other place or manner in the city than as herein provided: (1) Acceptable means of disposing of household sharp medical waste shall include: a. Disposal in an approved medical waste box, such as a sharps container; or b. Disposal in a heavy plastic container, such as a laundry soap bottle, providing that the lid is permanently affixed thereto using tape or other means, and the container is marked "medical waste: do not open". (2) No container for household sharp medical waste or loose household sharp medical waste may be mixed with recyclables. (3) The city's collector shall refuse to pick up any solid waste or recyclable material containing household sharp medical waste not separately contained and prepared as provided herein. (Ord. of 5-4-98(1), § 2) Secs. 62-123—62-140. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - FEES
Sec. 62-141. - Deposit. (a) The owner, tenant or occupant of the premises being furnished with garbage service shall deposit with the city manager a sanitation deposit in an amount set from time to time by council for residential service whenever the occupant, owner or tenant is not being furnished water to the premises and has not made the required utility deposit. The city manager shall issue his receipt for a deposit to the user on payment of the deposit. The deposit shall bear no interest and shall be kept by the city manager in a bank account separate from other funds and shall be used by the city only for the purpose of applying such deposit to unpaid and past due garbage charges and to pay for any lost or missing garbage roll-out carts. (b) If a garbage service user moves from the premises being furnished such services and he owes no unpaid garbage service bill to the city, the deposit shall be refunded to him without interest. (Ord. No. 2010-4, § 3, 3-1-10) Editor's note— Ord. No. 2010-4, § 3, adopted March 1, 2010, repealed former § 62-141, and enacted a new § 62-141 as set out herein. Former § 62-141 pertained to similar subject matter. See the Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. Sec. 62-142. - Monthly charges. It shall be the duty of the city manager to place into effect, with the approval of the mayor and council, a schedule of fees and charges for the collection of garbage, refuse, recyclable materials, and similar materials and, as often as it may appear necessary, to revise and adjust said schedules to produce funds sufficient to pay the operating expenses of regular sanitation service. (Ord. No. 2009-9, § 3, 8-17-09) Editor's note— Ord. No. 2009-9, § 3, adopted Aug. 17, 2009, deleted former § 62-142, and enacted a new § 62-142 as set out herein. (a) Fees for special collection service shall be computed on the basis of crew hours required to make the collection. (b) Fees due for special collection service may be billed along with the fee for water service, and shall be due and payable at the same time and under the same conditions as fees for water service. (Code 1976, § 4-2053) Sec. 62-144. - Due date for payment; authority to discontinue service. (a) Generally. All fees and charges for the collection of garbage, refuse and similar material shall be due and payable on the first day of each month in advance. When any user is 30 days delinquent in the payment of garbage service charges, the city may order the discontinuation of garbage service. All sanitary sewer, garbage and water service charges shall be due and payable on the first of each month. Upon the user becoming 30 days delinquent in the payment of such charges, the city may order the discontinuance of all such services. (b) Notice of discontinuance of service. Prior to the termination of garbage services to any property, a notice shall be transmitted to the person in whose name the account is established at such address as specified on the account. This notice of the discontinuation of such service may be incorporated in or transmitted with any regular or special billing and may be contained in the same notice for the discontinuation of water service. The notice shall contain the same language or similar language as provided in the notice specified in section 82-181 for the termination of water service. (c) Pickup of roll-out cart. Whenever garbage service is discontinued for nonpayment of the charges due the city, the city shall cause the garbage roll-out cart to be picked up by the city and there shall be a charge of $15.00 made by the city for picking up the garbage roll-out cart for the nonpayment of garbage service charges. If the roll-out cart is picked up by the city for nonpayment of garbage services, such services shall not be resumed or be reinstated until all accrued charges have been paid in full plus a charge of $15.00 for the picking up and redelivery of the roll-out garbage cart. (Code 1976, § 4-2052(c), (d), (f)) Sec. 62-145. - Lien for payment of charges. The owner of the premises and real property shall be liable for all garbage charges for services made available by the city. When charges are due and remain unpaid for a period of 60 days, the mayor and council may cause an execution to be issued by the city manager against the owner of the premises to which the garbage services are furnished, and any other persons as may be liable therefor. The execution shall be a lien upon the premises, and when recorded in the general execution docket of the county shall be a lien upon all the property of the defendant in execution from the date of such record. The execution may be levied by the marshal of the city or his deputy, and after advertisement and other proceedings as in the case of sales for the nonpayment of taxes, the property levied upon shall be sold at public outcry to the highest bidder, and such sale shall vest an absolute title in the purchaser; provided that the defendant shall have the right to file an affidavit denying that the whole or any part of the amount for which the execution is issued is due, and stating what amount he admits to be due. The amount so admitted to be due shall be paid or collected before the affidavit is received, and the affidavit received for the balance. All affidavits shall set out in detail the reasons why the affiant claims the amount is not due. When received by the city marshal, such affidavits shall be returned to the municipal court if the amount is $500.00 or under, and the superior court of the county if the amount contested is over $500.00, and there the matter shall be tried and the issue determined. (Ord. No. 2010-4, § 4, 3-1-10) Editor's note— Ord. No. 2010-4, § 4, adopted March 1, 2010, repealed former § 62-145, and enacted a new § 62-145 as set out herein. Sec. 62-166. - Findings. The mayor and council of Garden City, Georgia, hereby find that recycling will cause benefits by reducing demand on landfills and by conserving resources. Recycling will be encouraged and increased by having the city's waste management service equipment pick-up separated recyclable materials at residences utilizing roll-out carts for trash pick-up on a regular schedule. The mayor and council further find that, a survey of the residents having been taken and public hearings having been held, it appears that curbside pick-up of recyclable materials will be effective. (Ord. No. 2009-9, § 1, 8-17-09) Sec. 62-167. - Pick-up by city's waste management service of certain recyclable materials from residences utilizing roll-out carts for trash pick-up. Effective September 1, 2009, the following recyclable materials shall be picked-up by the city's waste management service from residences utilizing roll-out carts for trash pick-up: (1) Plastics (Category 1 (PETE), including drink bottles and milk trays); (2) Plastics (Category 2 (PETE), including bottles for milk, washing up liquids, etc.); (3) Glass (clear, brown, green); (4) Aluminum/cans; and, (5) Paper (including newspaper, cardboard, magazines, and phone books). The above-mentioned list is subject to change depending upon the increased or reduced capabilities of the city's waste management service provider. Persons desiring to take recyclables to pick-up locations operated by any public or private enterprise may do so, and thus bypass the city's curbside recycling program for some or all of their recycling needs. (Ord. No. 2009-9, § 1, 8-17-09) Sec. 62-168. - Obtaining Recyclable Containers. The container shall be furnished to the residence at no charge. (Ord. No. 2009-9, § 1, 8-17-09) Sec. 62-169. - Common location of collection of recyclable materials. The city manager shall provide a schedule to each resident requesting collection of recyclable materials which shall indicate the days on which such collection will be made. They shall be placed in such location on the day prior to collection and shall be removed no later than 7:00 p.m. on the date of collection. (Ord. No. 2009-9, § 1, 8-17-09) Sec. 62-170. - Unlawful to take recyclable materials. Recyclable materials shall become the property of the city when they are placed at the curbside for collection. (Ord. No. 2009-9, § 1, 8-17-09) Sec. 62-171. - Costs and revenues. No. 2009-9, § 1, 8-17-09) Sec. 62-172. - Recycling coordinator. (a) The collection of materials designated for recycling by the city shall be supervised by the city manager's office. (b) The city manager's office is authorized to promulgate reasonable regulations to implement the collection of recyclable materials as detailed in this article. (Ord. No. 2009-9, § 1, 8-17-09) Sec. 62-173. - Reserved. Editor's note— Ord. No. 2009-9, § 1, adopted Aug. 17, 2009, repealed § 62-173, which pertained to designated recovered materials and derived from Ord. of 10-4-93, § 7. Secs. 62-174—62-179. - Reserved. ARTICLE VII. - YARD TRIMMINGS DISPOSAL REGULATIONS
Sec. 62-180. - Definitions. As used in this article, the following terms shall have the meanings indicated: Commercial solid waste means all types of solid waste generated by stores, offices, restaurants, warehouses, and other non-manufacturing activities, excluding residential and industrial waste. Composting means the controlled biological decomposition of organic matter into stable, odor free humus. Leachate collection system means a system at a landfill for collection of the leachate which may percolate through the waste and into the soils surrounding the landfill. Municipal solid waste means any solid waste derived from households, including garbage, trash and sanitary waste in septic tanks and includes solid waste from single-family and multi-family residences, hotels, and motels, bunkhouses, campgrounds, picnic grounds, and day use recreation areas. The term includes yard trimmings and commercial solid waste but does not include solid waste from mining, agricultural, or silvicultural operations or industrial processes or operations. Municipal solid waste disposal facility means any facility or location where the final deposition of any amount of municipal solid waste occurs, whether or not mixed with or including commercial or industrial solid waste, including but not limited to municipal solid waste landfills. Municipal solid waste landfill means a disposal facility where any amount of the municipal solid waste, whether or not mixed with or including commercial waste, industrial waste, nonhazardous sludges or small quantity generator hazardous waste, is disposed of by means of placing an approved cover thereon. Yard trimmings means leaves, bush, grass clippings, shrub and tree prunings, discarded Christmas trees, nursery and greenhouse vegetative residuals, and vegetative matter resulting from landscaping, development and maintenance, other than mining, agricultural and silvicultural operations. (Ord. of 10-21-96(2), § 1) Sec. 62-181. - Placement and disposal; prohibitions. (a) It shall be unlawful to place or mix yard trimmings with municipal solid waste within the city limits. (b) Yard trimmings shall not be disposed at any municipal solid waste disposal facility having a liner and leachate collection system or requiring vertical expansion located within the city. (Ord. of 10-21-96(2), § 1) Sec. 62-182. - Sorting, storing, composting and collecting. Yard trimmings shall be handled in the following hierarchy: (1) Naturalized, low maintenance landscaping requiring little or no cutting; (2) Grass cycling by mowing it high and letting it lie; (3) Stacking branches into brush piles for use as wildlife habitats and for gradual decomposition into the soil; (4) Composting on the site where the material was grown, followed by incorporation of the finished compost into the soil at that site; (5) Chipping woody material on the site where such material was generated; (6) Collecting yard trimmings and transporting them to another site to be chipped or composted for later use; (7) Chipping woody material for later use as fiber fuel; and (8) Collecting yard trimmings and transporting them to solid waste facilities other than municipal solid waste disposal facilities which have a liner and leachate collection system or which continue to operate only because they have been approved for vertical expansion. (Ord. of 10-21-96(2), § 1) Sec. 62-183. - Penalties. Any person violating any section of this chapter shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00, by imprisonment for a term not to exceed 30 days, or by a combination of such fine and imprisonment. (Ord. of 10-21-96(2), § 1) Secs. 62-184—62-199. - Reserved. ARTICLE VIII. - PERMITTING AND REGULATION OF PRIVATELY OWNED AND/OR OPERATED SOLID WASTE TRANSFER STATIONS
Sec. 62-200. - Permit required. Permits issued by the city council shall be required for all privately owned and/or operated solid waste transfer stations. (Ord. of 11-17-97, § 2) Sec. 62-201. - Application for permits; fee; proof of financial ability. For each parcel of property for which a permit is sought, a separate application for a permit shall be filed with the director of public works, by the owner of the property and the proposed operator of the solid waste transfer station, containing: (1) The description, plat, ownership and present zoning of the land involved. (2) An engineering plan prepared by a professional engineer registered in the state, as required by the director of public works, which shall contain: a. Operation plan. An operation plan shall provide written instructions for the daily operation of the facility. The plan shall be revised when operational procedures change and such revisions shall be filed with the director of public works 30 days before taking effect. The plan shall include detailed procedures where applicable: 1. Identification of persons responsible for the operation and maintenance of the facility, including the ownership of the facility and corporate structure; 2. Adequate contingency operations, alternate waste handling and disposal methods in case of emergency such as a natural disaster or equipment failure; 3. Types of waste to be handled; 4. Methods for controlling a type of waste received at the facility. The plan shall specify inspection procedures, number and location of spotters, if applicable, and procedures to be followed if prohibited wastes are discovered; 5. Adequate vehicle traffic controls and unloading; 6. Adequate operations for gas, leachate, and stormwater control; 7. Adequate ground water and surface water monitoring systems; 8. Adequate type and capacity of equipment to be used; and 9. Adequate plans for fire, nuisance, water pollution, odor and vermin control. b. Reserved. (3) Such other information as the director of public works may reasonably require, including but not limited to, the business addresses of the applicant. (4) An application processing fee of $1,500.00. (5) Adequate proof of financial ability to perform under the terms and conditions of the proposed permit. (6) Adequate proof that the proposed site meets the requirements of the zoning code of the city. (7) All information submitted to the state environmental protection division of the state department of natural resources for the issuance of a general state permit. (Ord. of 11-17-97, § 2) Sec. 62-202. - Recommendations of director of public works. The director of public works shall review the permit application within 30 days of receipt and may, within said 30 days, request submittal of additional information needed for him to make an evaluation of the proposed facility. The director shall submit a written report and recommendation of approval or denial of a permit to the city council within 30 days after receipt of a completed application. An application shall be deemed complete 30 days from application or upon receipt of all information requested by the director during the initial 30 day period following application. The director's report may include recommended conditions. In reviewing the permit application, the director shall consider and include in his report a recommendation: (1) Whether the proposed method of operation will comply with the requirements of this Code, and with all state and federal laws and regulations. (2) Whether any hazard or menace to the public health would be created by the proposed use of the land involved or by the proposed method of operation. (3) Compliance with the zoning code of the city. (4) The impact of the proposed facility on surrounding and nearby land uses including those impacts caused by anticipated traffic patterns associated therewith. (5) Such other considerations as he deems relevant. (Ord. of 11-17-97, § 2) Sec. 62-203. - Council procedure. After receipt of the report or recommendation of the director of public works, but no more than 90 days after the application is complete, the city administrator shall schedule a public hearing before the city council in accordance with the following: (1) The city administrator shall provide at least 20 days notice of a hearing to be given by mail to the applicants. (2) The city clerk shall provide notice of the time and place of the public hearing which shall be given by mail to all owners of real property within 300 feet of the boundaries of the proposed facility. The applicants shall be responsible for providing the names and addresses of said owners to the city administrator. For purpose of notice requirements to adjoining owners, the names and addresses of these owners shall be deemed to be those on the current tax records of the property on file with the Chatham County Tax Assessor. Failure of the applicants or owners of real property required by this section to be notified by mail to receive the notice shall not invalidate or otherwise have any effect on the public hearing or action by the city council. (3) Notice of the public hearing held pursuant to this section shall be published once in a newspaper of general circulation not less than 30 days in advance of the date of the hearing. The published notice shall be in a form prescribed by the city administrator and shall be published by the applicant at its expense. The applicants shall file proof of publication with the city administrator prior to the public hearing. (4) The applicants shall post a sign on the property upon which the application is made in such form as required by the city administrator not less than 14 days prior to the date of the public hearing. The sign shall be posted in full view of the public on the street side of the land involved and shall be continuously maintained by the applicants until the public hearing before the city council. (5) Once begun pursuant to the notice herein, the public hearing may be continued, as necessary, as announced by the chair prior to the close of the public hearing. (Ord. of 11-17-97, § 2) Sec. 62-204. - Issuance of permit. (a) The city council may issue the permit with or without conditions if it finds that the facility satisfies the criteria properly considered by the director of public works. (b) No permit shall be issued until the proposed site has acquired all appropriate zoning designations, including but not limited to, necessary zoning classification, necessary land use designation, necessary variances and necessary exceptions. (Ord. of 11-17-97, § 2) Sec. 62-205. - Operation of solid waste transfer station. The following regulations apply to the operation of a privately owned and/or operated solid waste transfer station: (1) A solid waste transfer station shall be supervised during the hours of operation. The area shall be kept neat and sanitary and public access shall be controlled at all times. The director of public works may require that the solid waste transfer station be supervised at times other than during the hours of operation if necessary to prevent unlawful fires, unauthorized dumping or littering of nearby property. (2) Seepage, drainage, or escape of any material or gas from the facility which is an odor, nuisance or health hazard or which pollutes a stream is prohibited. (3) No asbestos, biomedical waste, hazardous waste, liquid waste, radioactive waste, or sludge, shall be handled at a solid waste transfer station. (4) Rodents shall be exterminated and insects shall be controlled at a solid waste transfer station. (5) There will be displayed at the entrance of each solid waste transfer station handling site a prominent sign stating the permit holder's name, address, and telephone of number and the phrase: "Operated Under City of Garden City Permit No. _____." (6) Any leachate emanating from a solid waste transfer station shall be collected and treated off-site to meet the applicable standards of state law. (7) A solid waste transfer station shall be operated to provide for the collection, control and treatment of surface water run-off from the site if necessary to meet applicable standards of state law. (8) The permit holders must provide the department of public works personnel, upon reasonable notice and upon presentation of appropriate credentials, access to the solid waste transfer station premises, at reasonable times, for the following purposes: a. Inspection of the facility, equipment, practices or operations regulated or required under the conditions of the permit; and b. Sampling or monitoring any substances or parameters at any location reasonably necessary to assure compliance with the permit. (9) The city shall have a right to be present whenever and shall be notified before ground or surface water samples or measurements are taken for required regulatory analysis and to receive promptly, upon request, a split sample and a copy of the analytical report. (10) The transfer station shall comply with all city ordinances, rules and regulations related to odor. (11) All unloading and storage areas shall be screened from view from adjacent properties occupied by residential, institutional, office and retail uses, and shall be conducted within an enclosed building when the property on which the facility is located is contiguous to, or across a right-of-way from, property having a residential classification or containing a residence. (12) The level of sound emitted from the facility shall not exceed: a. Fifty-five dBA when measured at the closest property line of residentially zoned property; or b. Sixty-five dBA when measured at the closest property line of property occupied by institutional, office, or retail uses. (13) The facility shall operate only between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. (Ord. of 11-17-97, § 2) Sec. 62-206. - Environmental damage insurance policy. (a) Required. The director of public works shall require, as a condition for the issuance of a permit under this article, to obtain and maintain in force an environmental damage insurance policy, a security bond, a self-insurance certificate or a trust bond certificate in the amount of $1,000,000.00. (b) Indemnification. The owners and/or operators of solid waste transfer stations shall indemnify the city against all claims of damages and responsibilities for clean-up due to environmental degradation of the air, land, surface water and groundwater within the jurisdiction of the city caused by the facility during the period in which such owner owns and such operator operates, the solid waste handling transfer station. (c) Proof of insurance. The owner and/or operator of a solid waste transfer station shall show proof of insurance, self-insurance, a trust fund certificate or a security bond before the owner and/or operator are issued the permit by the city. (d) Conflict with federal or state requirements. The requirements for obtaining and maintaining in force an environmental damage insurance policy, a security bond, a trust fund certificate, or a self-insurance certificate shall not be construed as usurping any financial requirements established by the United States Environmental Protection Agency of the state environmental protection division. (Ord. of 11-17-97, § 2) Sec. 62-207. - Correction of violations. The director of public works may issue an order to correct any violation of the conditions of the permit within a reasonable period of time as provided by the director. If the order is not obeyed, the director may suspend the permit, seek judicial penalties, and/or request injunctive relief. (Ord. of 11-17-97, § 2) Sec. 62-208. - Suspension, revocation, termination of permit; renewal application; and notification of transferred permit. (a) The director of public works may, by order, suspend the operation of any solid waste transfer station, and suspend the permit applicable thereto, for any violation of the requirements of this article or for violation of any condition of the permit. (b) The city council may, after notice and a public hearing, revoke a permit issued under this article for repeated or continual violations of this article's requirements or the conditions of the permit. (c) Operation of the facility following the revocation or suspension of the permit shall be a violation of this article. (d) In the event that the permit holders appeal the issues related to a suspension or revocation to a court of law and the city prevails, the city shall be entitled to reasonable attorneys' fees and costs. (e) An application for the renewal of the permit must be submitted six months prior to the expiration of the permit. The director of public works shall recommend conditions for the renewal permit and said requirements shall be designed to provide assurances that the continued operation of a facility will pose no significant threat to the public health or the environment. Renewal permits require the city council's approval and are discretionary. (f) In the event a permit is transferred, the permit holders have 90 days before transfer to notify the director of public works in writing regarding the transfer. The new owner and/or operator must disclose ownership and corporate structure and must submit proof of financial responsibility for operation of the facility. Transfer does not relieve any previous owner and/or operator of liability for any violation during the term of operation by the prior owner and/or operator. (Ord. of 11-17-97, § 2) Sec. 62-209. - Violations and penalties. (a) It is unlawful for any person to violate any provision of this article or an order of the director of public works entered pursuant to this article. (b) A person who knowingly, willfully, or with culpable negligence violates any provision of this article or an order of the director of public works entered pursuant to this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. (c) In addition to any other penalty, a person who violated any provision of this article shall be liable for several penalties of up to $2,000.00 per offense. Each day during any portion of which such violation occurs shall constitute a separate offense. Such civil penalty shall be collected in a civil action brought in the name of the city. (Ord. of 11-17-97, § 2) Sec. 62-210. - Financial responsibility. The holder and any transferee of a permit shall provide to the city a copy of any financial audit which may be required by state law by reason of owning and/or operating the transfer station, simultaneously with the submission of said audit to the state. Failure to supply such information shall constitute grounds for suspension and revocation of the permit. (Ord. of 11-17-97, § 2)

div.head: Chapter 66 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Charter reference— Streets, § 7.10. Cross reference— Amusements and entertainments, ch. 10; animals, ch. 14; buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; businesses, ch. 22; health and sanitation, ch. 42; offenses, ch. 58; parks and recreation, ch. 60; solid waste, ch. 62; subdivisions, ch. 70; traffic and vehicles, ch. 78; utilities, ch. 82; vehicles for hire, ch. 86; zoning, ch. 90. State Law reference— Authority to construct and maintain streets and roads, Ga. Const. art. 9, sec. 2, par. 3; powers with respect to municipal street system, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-92; power of city to open, close or extend public streets, alleys and sidewalks, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-3; street improvements, O.C.G.A. § 36-39-1 et seq.; executions for collection of assessments for paving streets and laying sewers, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-358.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 66-1. - Assembly on street or sidewalk. All crowds or assemblages of persons that congregate on the streets or sidewalks of the city, thereby obstructing the street to the inconvenience of pedestrians, shall be dispersed by the police, and any person who refuses to obey the warning of the officer shall be deemed to violate this section. (Code 1976, § 6-2001) State Law reference— Obstructing sidewalks or other public passages, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-43. Sec. 66-2. - Display of goods on sidewalk; obstructing street or sidewalk with vehicle. It shall be unlawful for any merchant or other person to exhibit or display any goods, wares or merchandise of any kind, or anything else, upon the sidewalks of the city, or to leave any delivery cart, wagon or other vehicle standing in or upon any street or sidewalk in such portion as will impede traffic. (Code 1976, § 6-2002) Sec. 66-3. - Obstructions on sidewalk generally. It shall be unlawful for any person to store, pile, deposit, erect, keep or place, or cause, permit or suffer to be stored, piled, deposited, erected, kept or placed, upon any sidewalk in the city, any wood, coal, boxes, barrels, stone, brick, lumber, dirt, merchandise, shipping case, stand, stall, booth or showcase or other obstruction of any kind, except as provided in this chapter or otherwise provided by law or ordinance. (Code 1976, § 6-2003) Sec. 66-4. - Construction near sidewalk. Before building or remodeling at any place where the building or remodeling is in close proximity to the sidewalk, a passageway shall be constructed so as to leave the sidewalk unobstructed and provide safe and easy passage. (Code 1976, § 6-2004) Sec. 66-5. - Sheds and awnings. No person shall erect or repair over any sidewalk or street any wooden shed or awning or any wooden shed for the support of an awning, or erect upon any street or sidewalk any post for the support of any awning. If any person shall violate this section, each day that the forbidden structure shall remain after notice shall constitute a separate violation. This section shall not be construed to prevent the erection over the sidewalk of cloth or metal awnings supported upon metallic frames firmly suspended from the building and at least seven feet above the level of the sidewalk. (Code 1976, § 6-2005) Sec. 66-6. - Impeding travel on street. No person shall obstruct or impede travel on any street in the corporate limits of the city. (Code 1976, § 6-2006) Sec. 66-7. - Playing games on street or sidewalk. No person shall play baseball, football or any other game of ball, or shall pitch or catch a ball, on any street or sidewalk within the fire limits of the city. (Code 1976, § 6-2007) Sec. 66-8. - Cleanup of litter in parking and access areas. (a) Responsibilities of owner or occupant. Every owner, lessee, tenant, occupant or other person in charge of any commercial establishment or premises which maintains any paved or unpaved areas for the use of the public, either for parking or access areas, incident to the carrying on of the principal business of any such commercial establishment or premises, which parking or access areas abut on or lie within ten feet of any public street or other public way, shall keep and maintain such areas clean and free from trash, litter, rubbish and any materials liable to be blown, deposited or cast upon such street or other public way. (b) Suitable receptacles required. Suitable receptacles shall be provided in all parking or access areas within the meaning of subsection (a) of this section. Such receptacles shall be plainly marked and constructed to prevent scattering of any trash, litter, rubbish or other materials deposited therein. (Code 1976, §§ 6-2011, 6-2012) Sec. 66-9. - Permitting oil or similar material to flow into street or drainage ditch. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to cause or permit petroleum products, coal oil or any other oil or lubricating fluid to fall or flow on, over or into any street or drainage ditch within the corporate limits of the city. (b) Any person using, handling or otherwise dealing in petroleum products, coal oil or any other oil or lubricating fluid shall provide adequate traps to catch and eliminate such products before disposing of any such waste. (c) Any person violating any of the provisions of this section, upon conviction in the municipal court, shall be punished as provided in section 1-13. (Code 1976, § 6-2013) Sec. 66-10. - Solicitation for contributions within the right-of-way of streets and highways. Charitable organizations registered in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 43-17-5 and such organizations exempt from registration in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 43-17-9 are authorized to solicit for contributions on the streets and highways within the city, subject to compliance with the requirements set forth herein. Charitable organizations seeking a permit pursuant to this section shall file an application, in the form provided by the city, with the city administrator. Such application shall include the name, address, and telephone number of the organization, the officers of the organization, the date(s), time(s), and place(s) of the proposed solicitation and must include an agreement by the organization to hold harmless and indemnify the city from liability for damage or injury arising out of the permitted solicitation. Such application must be executed by a duly authorized officer of said organization. Such organization must provide a copy of the declaration page of a liability insurance policy which provides liability insurance coverage, with limits of at least $1,000,000.00 per occurrence, for the permitted solicitation. Such policy shall include an endorsement listing the city as a named insured. The cost of the permit for solicitation shall be $100.00. In the event the solicitation will continue more than one day, an additional fee in the amount of $25.00 per day will be imposed. Solicitation for contributions on the streets and highways within the street without a permit shall be punished as a misdemeanor. (Ord. of 10-21-96(3), § 1) Editor's note— Section 1 of an ordinance adopted Oct. 21, 1996, set out provisions intended for use as § 78-71. For purposes of classification, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as § 66-10. Sec. 66-11. - Special street cleaning or repair—When. (a) The words "special cleaning or repair," as used in sections 66-11 through 66-13 shall include cleaning, resurfacing, restoration of gravel and similar repairs made necessary by prohibited acts, neglect, or conditions. (b) Any act, neglect, or omission or any condition caused or allowed to continue which creates, results in, or causes a condition in or upon any public street, sidewalk, or storm drain which requires special cleaning or repair of such street, sidewalk or storm drain is hereby prohibited. (c) Prohibited acts, neglect, omissions, and conditions which result in requiring special cleaning or repair of such street shall include, but not be limited to: (1) The hauling of dirt, debris, and materials removed from the sites of construction or reconstruction of buildings or structures, or waste materials of any kind, in such manner that any portion of such dirt, debris, or materials is spilled, lost, dropped or left upon the streets or sidewalks. (2) Depositing or leaving upon the streets or sidewalks or other ways, of mud, dirt, or other material as the result of the use of trucks, construction equipment or machinery, regardless of whether such materials are spilled, lost, or dropped in transit or, are deposited upon the surface of the street or public property by the tires and wheels of such trucks, construction equipment or machinery. (3) The grading of lots, or other land at elevations higher than the street, sidewalk, or other way, or any other acts, neglects, or conditions created or allowed to exist upon such property which result in mud, dirt, soil, gravel, debris or other materials being washed onto streets or sidewalks or into the storm drainage system. (4) The tearing up of streets or sidewalks or other ways as a result of the use of trucks, construction equipment, or machinery coming to and from construction sites. (d) Special cleaning or repairing of streets, sidewalks, and the storm drainage system shall be deemed to be required when their condition is such that the public health, safety, welfare, or public use of the same is threatened, limited, or impaired; the use and enjoyment of property abutting such streets or sidewalks is diminished or limited; or substantial damage is caused to the streets, sidewalks, or drainage facilities or to such abutting property. (Ord. No. 2002-7, § 1, 5-6-02) Sec. 66-12. - Same—Action by. (a) Any person whose act, neglect, or omission causes or permits a condition to exist or continue upon any street, sidewalk, or other way, or in any storm drain, which condition requires special cleaning or repair shall, upon receipt of written notice from the city, perform such special cleaning and repair upon and to such street, sidewalk, or storm drain. (b) Upon failure of the person responsible to perform special cleaning and repair after notice, the director of public works may cause the same to be performed by his department, and in such event shall keep records of the costs of such work, which may be computed on the basis of reasonably established per-mile, or per-hour, or both costs of the use of equipment, plus labor and materials, including water, likewise computed at the cost to the city. (c) Whenever any construction work is being performed in a manner as to violate subsection (a) above and to create a hazardous condition, the mayor may order the specific part of such work which is creating the violation to be immediately stopped. The order to stop shall be in writing to the person whose act, neglect, or omission causes or permits a condition to exist or continue, and should state the specific work to be stopped, the specific reasons therefor, and the conditions under which the work may be resumed. Violation of a stop order shall constitute an offense under this Code and shall be punished as provided in section 1-13 of this Code. For any offense continued from day to day, each day's continuance thereof shall be deemed a separate offense. (Ord. No. 2002-7, § 1, 5-6-02) Sec. 66-13. - Same—Penalties; payment of. (a) Any person whose act, neglect, or omission or who, by permitting a condition to continue (whether done or neglected directly or through an agent, servant or employee), causes additional expense to the city for necessary special cleaning or repairs shall reimburse the city for its expenses upon receipt of an itemized statement of expenses submitted by the city, and upon failure to reimburse the city shall incur and be liable to the city for a civil penalty of $1,000.00, in addition to such expenses. (b) The department of public works shall send to any person responsible for additional expense to the city an itemized statement of the expense incurred and request for reimbursement. The city attorney is authorized to bring suit in the name of the city to recover any such unpaid expenses and civil penalties. (Ord. No. 2002-7, § 1, 5-6-02) Sec. 66-14. - Prohibiting the placement of junk and debris on any public road, right-of-way, street, and alley. It shall be unlawful for any person to place, cause, or allow to be thrown or disposed of in any manner any litter, garbage, waste, rubbish, automobile parts, debris, furniture, glass, oil, filthy or odoriferous objects, or anything else of an unsightly or unsanitary nature along or near or on any public road, right-of-way, street, or alley, in the city, except in an authorized litter receptacle maintained on public property for that specific use. (Ord. No. 2002-6, § 1, 5-6-02) Editor's note— Ord. No. 2002-6, § 1, adopted May 6, 2002, set out provisions intended for use as § 66-10. Inasmuch as there were already provisions so designated, these provisions have been included as § 66-14 at the discretion of the editor. Secs. 66-15—66-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - STREET EXCAVATIONS[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Cross reference— Environment, ch. 30. State Law reference— Obstructing, encroaching on, or injuring public roads, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-1.
Sec. 66-31. - Permit. (a) Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to open or make any excavation in any street in the city without first securing a permit therefor as provided in this section. (b) Application. Any person who shall desire to make any opening or excavation of any kind in the streets of the city shall make application to the mayor therefor in writing. Such application shall be made upon blanks to be furnished by the mayor, and shall set forth the name of the applicant, the exact location of the proposed opening or excavation and the approximate size or depth thereof. The application shall contain an agreement on the part of the applicant that the work shall be done in full compliance with all of the ordinances of the city and the laws of the state in relation thereto and that the applicant shall truly save, defend and keep harmless the city from and indemnify it against any and all actions, suits, demands, payments, costs and charges for any reason arising from the proposed opening or excavation and all damages to persons and property resulting in any manner therefrom or from occupying the street in the prosecution of the work connected therewith or from any other matter, cause or thing relating thereto. (c) Fee; bond. Before any permit shall be issued to open or excavate any street in the city, the applicant shall pay to the mayor a permit fee fixed by the council to cover the cost of inspection and other incidental services in connection therewith. Before any permit shall be issued, the mayor shall determine the amount of the bond to be given to cover the proper restoration of the area to be disturbed by the applicant. The amount of the bond shall be determined at a rate fixed by the council, and the bond shall be conditioned upon the faithful performance and prompt payment of all matters as set forth in this article. Such bond shall be furnished prior to the granting of the permit as provided for in this section. (Code 1976, §§ 4-1001—4-1003) Sec. 66-32. - Payment of costs; supervision and approval of work. All work in connection with the opening of any street, including the excavation, protection, refilling, temporary paving or permanent paving, shall be done by the applicant at his own expense, subject to the supervision and approval of the mayor; provided that the mayor may require that the cutting of the surface of improved streets and the backfilling of all excavations therein be done by the city and the charge therefor paid by the applicant. The bond as provided for in this article shall not be released within the period of two years after the completion of the backfilling without a certificate of the mayor given within that period that the work of the applicant has been approved. (Code 1976, § 4-1005) Sec. 66-33. - Excavations extending across more than half of street. No opening or excavation in any street shall extend from the curbline into a street a distance greater than one foot beyond the centerline of the street before being refilled and the surface of the street restored to a condition safe and convenient for travel. (Code 1976, § 4-1006(a)) Sec. 66-34. - Interference with water mains or sewers. The work of an excavation shall be so conducted as not to interfere with water mains or sewers or their connections with buildings, until permission of the proper authorities in connection with such subsurface lines or construction shall have been obtained. (Code 1976, § 4-1006(b)) Sec. 66-35. - Protection of public safety; indemnification of city. During the making of any excavation in any street, every necessary and reasonable precaution shall be taken by the applicant and the parties making the excavation to keep the street in a safe and passable condition, both day and night, by guards, barriers, lanterns and other devices. All permits issued under this article are granted under and subject to the express condition that the person to whom the permit is issued shall indemnify, save and keep harmless the city from any loss, in damage or otherwise, which may be occasioned at any time by an excavation, or by any leak, explosion or other injury from any pipe, conduit or any other matter placed in the excavation. (Code 1976, § 4-1006(c)) Sec. 66-36. - Correction of unsatisfactory work. If any work performed by or for a permit holder under this article shall, in the opinion of the mayor, be unsatisfactory, and the work is not corrected to his satisfaction within the time fixed by him, the city may proceed to correct such unsatisfactory work and charge the cost thereof to the applicant. (Code 1976, § 4-1006(d)) Sec. 66-37. - Backfilling and restoration of surface. Any person who shall open or excavate any street in the city shall thoroughly and completely refill the opening or excavation so as to prevent any settling thereof and shall restore the surface to the same condition as it was before the opening or excavation. The surface shall conform to the grade and be of the same surface as that part of the thoroughfare immediately adjoining the opening. If within two years after the restoration of the surface as provided in this section defects shall appear there resulting from defective backfilling by the applicant, the applicant shall reimburse the city for the cost of all necessary repairs to the permanent paving for four inches of cement and at least two inches of asphalt. (Code 1976, § 4-1004) Sec. 66-38. - Emergency work. If any emergency shall arise it shall be lawful for the person owning or responsible for the pipe, line, construction or apparatus, where necessary, to commence an excavation to remedy such condition before securing a permit as required by this article, provided that the application for permit shall not be later than the next business day thereafter and all other provisions of this article shall be fully complied with. If any emergency condition shall not be immediately attended to by the owner or person responsible, the mayor, after such notice as he shall deem necessary, shall proceed to direct the work required by such emergency and charge the costs for such work to the person responsible. (Code 1976, § 4-1007) Sec. 66-39. - Payment of charges for work done by city. Payment for all work done by the city pursuant to this article shall be made by the person responsible therefor under the provisions of this article within 30 days after a bill is sent to such person by the clerk. Upon failure to pay such charge within such time, the charge shall be collectible by the city in the manner provided by law for the collection of municipal claims. (Code 1976, § 4-1008) Secs. 66-40—66-60. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION AND REPAIR
Sec. 66-61. - Responsibility for construction and repair. The grading, paving and repairing of all sidewalks and pavements thereon along the streets shall be done by the owners of the lots fronting thereon. (Code 1976, § 4-1011) Sec. 66-62. - Construction or repair by city. On the neglect or refusal of the owner of the lot fronting thereon to grade, pave or repave or repair any sidewalk or pavement after 30 days' notice so to do from the council, the city, through its proper officials, shall cause the work to be done and shall collect from such owner of the lot the cost thereof, together with all charges and expenses, and, if such charges are not paid, shall file a municipal lien therefor against such lot. (Code 1976, § 4-1013) Sec. 66-63. - Correction of unsatisfactory work. If any owner of a lot fronting or abutting on any street in the city shall violate the provisions of this article by paving the sidewalk in front of his property with materials not specified in this article or by laying the pavement on any other than the established grade or in any other manner than as provided in this article, the council shall serve notice on the owner to regrade and repave the sidewalk to conform to the provisions of this article within 30 days after the service of the notice. Upon the failure of the owner to regrade and repave the sidewalk within the time stipulated, the council shall cause such sidewalk to be regraded and repaved in the manner required by this article. The council shall collect the cost thereof, together with all charges and expenses, from the owner of the lot as provided in section 66-62, according to law. (Code 1976, § 4-1014) Sec. 66-64. - Repaving of existing sidewalks not constructed in accordance with article. No pavement heretofore laid with materials not prescribed in this article or in a different manner than that specified in this article shall be permitted to be repaired as a whole, or to be repaved with any other material or in any other manner than that specified in this article. Whenever any such pavement becomes, in the opinion of the council, in unsafe condition, notice shall be served upon the owners of the lots fronting thereon to regrade and repave with the material and in the manner provided in this article. Upon the failure of the owners to do so, after 30 days' notice, the council shall cause the work to be done, and the cost thereof, with any expenses, shall be collected by the city from the owners as provided in section 66-62. (Code 1976, § 4-1015) Sec. 66-65. - Construction specifications. (a) The material to be used in the paving of all sidewalks on streets where the street or roadway has been improved by paving and curbing shall be flagstone or concrete. If of flagstone, the flagstone shall be of good hard and durable sandstone not less than two inches thick and shall be cut and sawed with straight edges and fit closely at the joints and shall be evenly and closely laid. If of concrete, the manner of constructing the sidewalk shall be as follows: (1) All ground shall be excavated to a depth of 15 inches below the grade of the street. (2) The foundation shall be made of ten inches of good coke cinders, furnace ashes or broken stone, dampened and well tamped. (3) The pavement shall be constructed of not less than four inches of concrete well tamped and properly scored and finished with not less than one inch of top coating. (4) The concrete shall be composed of one part good Portland cement, three parts good, clean sharp river sand and five parts broken stone or river gravel. (5) The top coat shall be made of one part good Portland cement and 1½ parts clean sharp river sand. (6) All stone and gravel used in the concrete shall be of a size that will pass through a three-inch ring. (7) In all cases, the pavement shall be laid to the line and grade. (b) The material to be used in the paving of all sidewalks on streets where the street or roadway has not been improved by paving and curbing may be flagstone or concrete as specified in subsection (a) of this section, or the sidewalk may be paved with good hard brick placed on a firm foundation of sufficient depth and drainage to make an even and firm brick sidewalk. (c) If a property owner in the city wishes to install a new sidewalk or replace an existing sidewalk with one which could be classified as a decorative sidewalk, he must submit a set of plans and specifications to the council for approval. These plans and specifications must be equal to the requirements set out in subsections (a) and (b) of this section as to base, thickness and strength, but the top may be of different types of materials, as long as the council is satisfied that it will meet the spirit of this article. If the council decides that the proposed sidewalk meets the spirit of this article, it may grant a specific exception. (Code 1976, § 4-1012) Sec. 66-66. - Grant of right to install fiber optic cables within city right-of-way. Any person required to apply for permit under section 66-31, which furnishes telecommunications services and which desires to occupy, use, or place its fiber optic cables in the right-of-way, is hereby granted the right to do so if and only so long as its complies with all the other requirements of the City Code and state law. This section does not apply to a person which uses and occupies the rights-of-way for the purpose of operating its business when there is a franchise agreement between that person and the city. The granting of such rights is expressly conditioned on, and is subject to, continuing compliance with all provisions of law. (Ord. No. 2001-2, § 1, 1-16-01) Sec. 66-67. - Right of way fiber optic cable installation—Mapping data. Each person seeking permission to install fiber optic cables within the city's right-of-way shall provide the city administrator information indicating the horizontal and appropriate vertical location, relative to the boundaries of the right-of-way, of the fiber optic cables which it owns or over which it has control and which shall be located in any right-of-way. The city shall have the power to prohibit or limit the placement of fiber optic cables within its right-of-way if there is insufficient space to accommodate the applicant's request to occupy and use the right-of-way. In making such decisions, the city shall strive to the extent possible to accommodate all existing and potential users of the right-of-way, but shall be guided primarily by considerations of the public interest, the condition of the right-of-way, the protection of existing equipment in the right-of-way, and future city plans for public improvements and projects which have been determined to be in the public interest. The permittee shall provide as-built drawings detailing the location of the fiber optic conduits and manholes installed pursuant to the authorization granted herein. (Ord. No. 2001-2, § 1, 1-16-01) Sec. 66-68. - Same—Relocation of cables. The city shall have the right to request that a person promptly and at its own expense, permanently remove and relocate its fiber optic cables located in the right-of-way and restore the right-of-way to the same condition it was prior to said removal or relocation whenever the city determines that the person's cables interferes with (a) a present or future city use of the right-of-way; (b) a public improvement undertaken by the city; (c) the public health, safety, and welfare; or (d) the safety and convenience of ordinary travel over the right-of-way. Notwithstanding the foregoing, a person shall not have to remove or relocate its fiber optic cables from any right-of-way which has been vacated in favor of a non-governmental entity unless and until the reasonable costs thereof are first paid to the person therefor. (Ord. No. 2001-2, § 1, 1-16-01) Sec. 66-69. - Same—Right-of-way restoration. The work to be done under the permit for the installation of fiber optic cables within the city's right-of-way, and the repair and restoration of the right-of-way as required herein, must be completed within the dates specified in the permit issued pursuant to section 66-31, increased by as many days as work could not be done because of circumstances beyond the control of the permittee or when work was prohibited as unseasonable or unreasonable. (Ord. No. 2001-2, § 1, 1-16-01) Sec. 66-70. - Same—Supplementary applications. A permit issued under section 66-31 for the installation of fiber optic cables within the city's right-of-way is valid only for the area of the right-of-way specified in the permit. No permittee may perform any work outside the area specified in the permit, except as provided herein. Any permittee which determines that an area of greater size than that specified in the permit must be excavated must before working in that greater area: (a) make application for a permit extension and pay any additional fees necessitated thereby, and (b) be granted a new permit or permit extension. A permit issued hereunder is valid only for the dates specified in the permit. No permittee may begin its work before the permit start date or, except as provided herein, continue working after the end date. If a permittee does not finish the work by the permit end date, it must make application for a new permit for the additional time it needs, and receive the new permit or an extension of the old permit before working after the end date of the previous permit. This supplementary application must be done before the permit end date. (Ord. No. 2001-2, § 1, 1-16-01) Sec. 66-71. - Same—Permitting fee. In addition to the fees charged pursuant to sections 66-31(b) and 66-32, the permit applicant shall pay $1.00 per linear foot on an annual basis for the placement of fiber optic cables in the city's right-of-ways as of January 1 of each year. The first payment under Ordinance No. 2001-2 shall be prorated from the effective date to the end of the year and shall be due within 30 days from the effective date. Payment in advance for each subsequent year shall be remitted by January 30. This fee may be adjusted annually by the mayor and council. (Ord. No. 2001-2, § 1, 1-16-01) Sec. 66-72. - Same—Installation requirements. The excavation, backfilling, restoration, and all other work performed in the right-of-way in connection with the installation, maintenance, repair, operation, and removal of fiber optic cables shall be done in conformance with sections 66-32 and 66-37. The work shall be done at the permittee's sole cost and expense without risk or liability on the city's part. (Ord. No. 2001-2, § 1, 1-16-01) Sec. 66-73. - Same—Insurance information. In addition to the information required to be submitted pursuant to section 66-31, any person seeking to install underground fiber optic cables in the city's right-of-way shall provide the city administrator within a certificate of insurance or self-insurance which (a) verifies that an insurance policy has been issued to the applicant by an insurance company licensed to do business in the State of Georgia, or is covered by self-insurance which provides the city with protections equivalent to that of a Georgia licensed insurance company, legally independent from the applicant, and (b) verifies that the applicant is insured against claims for personal injury, including death, as well as claims for property damage arising out of the (1) use and occupancy of the right-of-way by the applicant, its officers, agents, employees, and permittees, and (2) placement and use of fiber optic cables in the city's right-of-way by the applicant, its officers, agents, employees, and permittees, including, but limited to, protection against liability arising from completed operations, damage of underground equipment, and collapse of property, (3) names the city as an additional insured as to whom the required coverages herein are in force and applicable and for whom defense will be provided as to all such coverages, (4) requires that the city be notified 30 days in advance of cancellation of the policy, and (5) indicates comprehensive liability coverage, automobile liability coverage, and umbrella coverage in amounts established by the city administrator sufficient to protect the city. (Ord. No. 2001-2, § 1, 1-16-01) Sec. 66-74. - Same—Indemnification and liability. In addition to the indemnification and liability provided for in sections 66-31(b) and 66-35, by accepting a permit hereunder for the installation of fiber optic cables within the city's right-of-way, a permittee is required to defend, indemnify, and hold the city whole and harmless from all costs, liabilities, and claims for damages of any kind arising out of the construction, presence, installation, maintenance, repair or operation of its equipment, or out of any activity undertaken by it in or near a right-of-way, whether or not any act or omission complained of is authorized, allowed, or prohibited by a right-of-way permit. It further agrees that it will not bring, nor cause to be brought, any action, suit, or other proceeding claiming damages, or seeking any other relief against the city for any claim nor for any award arising out of the presence, installation, maintenance, or operation of its fiber optic cables, or any activity undertaken in or near a right-of-way, whether or not the act or omission complained of is authorized, allowed, or prohibited by a right-of-way permit. The foregoing does not indemnify the city for its own negligence except for claims arising out of or alleging the city's negligence where such negligence arises out of or is primarily related to the presence, installation, construction, operation, maintenance or repair of the permittee's equipment by the permittee or on the permittee's behalf, including, but not limited to the issuance of permits and inspection of plans or work. This section is not, as to third parties, a waiver of any defense of immunity otherwise available to the city; and the permittee in defending any action of behalf of the city, shall be entitled to assert in any action every defense or immunity that the city could assert on its own behalf. (Ord. No. 2001-2, § 1, 1-16-01) Sec. 66-75. - Same—Right-of-way vacation. If the city vacates a right-of-way which contains the fiber optic cables of a permittee, the city shall reserve, to and for itself and all permittees having cables in the vacated right-of-way, the right to install, maintain and operate any equipment in the vacated right-of-way and to enter upon such right-of-way at any time for the purpose of reconstructing, inspecting, maintaining, or repairing the same. (Ord. No. 2001-2, § 1, 1-16-01) Sec. 66-76. - Same—Abandoned or unusable cables. A permittee who has determined to discontinue its cable operations in the city must either (a) provide information satisfactory to the city that the permittee's obligations for its cables in the right-of-way under this chapter have been lawfully assumed by another permittee; or (b) submit to the city a proposal and instruments for transfer and ownership of its cables to the city. If a permittee proceeds under this clause, the city may, at its option, (a) purchase the equipment, or (b) require the permittee at its own expense, to remove it, or (c) require the permittee to post a bond in an amount sufficient to reimburse the city for reasonably anticipated costs to be incurred in removing the cables. Cables of a permittee who fails to comply with the proceeding paragraph and which, for two years, remains unused shall be deemed to abandoned. Abandoned equipment is deemed to be a nuisance. The city may exercise any remedies or rights it may have at law or in equity, including, but not limited to, (a) abating the nuisance, (b) taking possession of the cables and restoring them to a usable condition, or (c) requiring removal of the cables by the permittee or by the permittee's surety under the bond required hereunder. Any permittee who has unusable cables in any right-of-way shall remove them from that right-of-way unless this requirement is waived by the city. (Ord. No. 2001-2, § 1, 1-16-01) Sec. 66-77. - Same—Other obligations. Obtaining a right-of-way permit for the installation of fiber optic cables does not relieve the permittee of its duty to obtain all other necessary permits, licenses, and authority and to pay all fees required by any other governmental entity, or by laws or regulations. The permittee shall perform all work in conformance with all applicable codes and established rules and regulations, and it is responsible for all work done in the right-of-way pursuant to its permit, regardless of who performs the work. Except in the case of an emergency, and with the approval of the city administrator, no right-of-way excavation may be performed when conditions are unreasonable for such work. (Ord. No. 2001-2, § 1, 1-16-01) Sec. 66-78. - Same—Revocation of permits. Permittees hold permits issued pursuant to this chapter for the installation of fiber optic cables as a privilege and not as a right. The city reserves its right, as provided herein, to revoke any right-of-way permit, without fee refund, in the event of a substantial breach of the terms and conditions of any statute, ordinance, rule or regulation, or any condition of the permit. If the city administrator determines that the permittee has committed a substantial breach of a term or condition of any statute, ordinance, rule, regulation, or any condition of the permit, the city administrator shall make a written demand upon the permittee to remedy such violation. The demand shall state that continued violations may be cause for revocation of the permit. Further, a substantial breach, as stated above, will allow the city administrator, at his discretion, to place additional or revised conditions on the permit. Within 24 hours of receiving notification of the breach, permittee shall contact the city administrator with a plan, acceptable to the city administrator, for its correction. Permittee's failure to so contact the city administrator, or the permittee's failure to submit an acceptable plan, or permittee's failure to reasonably implement the approved plan, shall be cause for immediate revocation of the permit. If the permit is revoked, the permittee shall also reimburse the city for the city's reasonable costs, including restoration costs and the costs of collection and reasonable attorneys' fees incurred in connection with such revocation. (Ord. No. 2001-2, § 1, 1-16-01) Sec. 66-79. - Same—No assignment of permits. The right to install underground fiber optic cables within the city's rights-of-way shall not be assigned or transferred, directly or indirectly, without the prior written consent of the city. (Ord. No. 2001-2, § 1, 1-16-01) Secs. 66-80—66-85. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - DRAINAGE DITCHES
Sec. 66-86. - Penalty for violation of article. Any person violating any provision of this article, upon conviction in the municipal court, shall be punished as provided in section 1-13. (Code 1976, § 5-2021) Sec. 66-87. - Obstruction. It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct, block, divert or otherwise interfere with the flow of water within the drainage ditches and roadside ditches in the corporate limits of the city. (Code 1976, § 5-2018) Sec. 66-88. - Installation of culverts. (a) Permit required. No person shall install a culvert in a roadside ditch or drainage ditch until a permit has been issued in accordance with subsection (b) of this section by the city administrator. (b) Application for permit; drainage plan; inspection. (1) Any person desiring to install a culvert in any drainage ditch or roadside ditch shall first make application for a permit to the city for permission to install the culvert. The application shall be accompanied by a drawing showing the location, grade, size of pipe, other drainage structures and the angle of the culvert to be installed. The maximum length of culvert to be installed in any drainage ditch or roadside ditch shall not exceed 400 feet between drainage structures. (2) All drainage plans are to be prepared and certified by an engineer licensed to perform engineering work in the state. The engineer shall certify on the plans that the drainage structures shall have no adverse effect upon any property or any improvements lying upstream or downstream from the proposed culvert and drainage structures, and shall further certify that the drainage structures shall not cause flooding or ponding of water upon any property lying upstream or downstream from such proposed culvert and drainage structure. (3) All drainage plans submitted by a licensed engineer must be approved by the city prior to any improvements being made. It is the responsibility of the applicant to include in the drainage plan sufficient information for the city to properly evaluate the plan and to inspect the work while being performed. (4) Upon issuance of a permit, the person having the culvert installed must notify the city prior to covering the culvert and shall not cover the culvert until the work has been inspected by the city. (5) Any person desiring to install a culvert in a driveway with a length equal to or less than 29 feet shall not be required to submit a plan as provided in subsection (b)(2) of this section. (c) [ Installation of pipe upon request and reimbursement of cost by property owners. ] The city, upon request by property owners, may install pipe in roadside ditches whenever feasible and economically viable to eliminate unnecessary road and ditch maintenance, provided the owners of the properties adjoining the ditches reimburse the city for the cost of the pipe. Pipe costs must be paid in advance. (Code 1976, §§ 5-2019, 5-2020; Ord. of 6-16-86, § 3; Ord. of 2-19-96(2), § 1) Secs. 66-89—66-110. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - PARADES AND DEMONSTRATIONS[3] Footnotes: --- (3) --- State Law reference— Preventing or disrupting lawful procession, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-34; operation of motorcycles and motor vehicles in parades, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-7; funeral processions, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-76.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 66-111. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Block means that portion of any street lying between its intersections with other streets. Group demonstration means any assembly together or concert of action between or among two or more persons for the purpose of protesting any matter or of making known any position or promotion of such persons, or on behalf of any organization or class of persons, or for the purpose of attracting attention to such assembly. Parade means any assemblage of two or more persons participating in or operating any vehicle in any march, ceremony, show, exhibition or procession of any kind in or upon the public streets, sidewalks, alleys, parks or other public grounds or places. Picket line means any two or more persons formed together for the purpose of making known any position or promotion of such persons, or on behalf of any organization or class of persons. (Code 1976, § 6-2021) Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. Sec. 66-112. - Prohibited acts. The following acts or activities, when performed or undertaken in conjunction with or as a part of any parade, picket line or group demonstration, are hereby prohibited and declared unlawful: (1) The carrying on or about the person of any firearm, or any other weapon or article, including but not limited to blackjacks, nightsticks or flashlights, which by its use might constitute a deadly weapon; or (2) The taking or keeping of any dog or other vicious animal, whether leashed or unleashed. (Code 1976, § 6-2025) Sec. 66-113. - Interference with parade or demonstration. No person shall hamper, obstruct, impede or interfere with any parade, picket line or group demonstration being conducted under authority of a permit duly issued by the chief of police. (Code 1976, § 6-2027) Sec. 66-114. - Picketing. Picket lines and picketing shall be subject to the following regulations: (1) Picketing may be conducted only on the sidewalks reserved for pedestrian movement, and may not be conducted on the portion of a street used primarily for vehicular traffic. (2) Not more than ten pickets promoting the same objective shall be permitted to use either of the two sidewalks within a single block at any one time. (3) Pickets may carry written or printed placards or signs not exceeding two feet in width. (Code 1976, § 6-2028) Secs. 66-115—66-125. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - PERMIT
Sec. 66-126. - Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to organize, conduct or participate in any parade, picket line or group demonstration in or upon any street, sidewalk, alley or other public place within the city unless a permit therefor has been issued by the city in accordance with the provisions of this division. (Code 1976, § 6-2022) Sec. 66-127. - Prerequisites for issuance. The chief of police or his designee shall issue permits as required in this division, and in the issuance thereof he shall: (1) Require a written application for a permit to be filed not less than 24 hours in advance of such parade, picket line or group demonstration, which application shall specify the time and place for the commencement of any such picket line and the time, place, route and duration of any such parade or group demonstration. (2) Require that the application for a permit specify whether or not minors below the age of 18 years will be permitted to participate. (3) Require that the application for a permit shall specify and the permit shall designate the person in charge of the activity. Such person shall be required to accompany the parade, picket line or group demonstration and shall carry such permit with him at the time. Such permit shall not be valid in the possession of any other person. (Code 1976, § 6-2024) Sec. 66-128. - Standards for issuance.
